  • Screening for opportunistic infections (including TB) should be done at every visit by utilizing the clinical assessment approach of thorough history taking and physical examination.
  • OIs should be managed according to the recommended protocols.
  • If OIs are not treated on time may hasten progression of HIV with poor outcomes.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-320-Care Tx-Patient given cotrimoxazole and correct return date'
column5: 'Patient given cotrimoxazole and correct return date'
column6:
'

Ensure patient has enough Cotrimoxazole for prophylaxis and agree on return date.

  • All HIV positive patients should be put on daily Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis, unless contra-indicated/allergic to prevent opportunistic infections. Patients allergic to cotrimoxazole should be put on dapsone.
  • Proper adherence counselling should be provided prior to initiation of Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis.
  • Follow up dates should be given in accordance with the recommended guidelines/SOPs.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-330-Care Tx-Correct filling of the data tools- ANC booklet (PMCTC only), Blue card, pre- ART and ART registers'
column5: 'Correct filling of the data tools- ANC booklet (PMCTC only), Blue card, pre- ART and ART registers'
column6:
'

Fill in required information in appropriate standardized data collection tools

  • Providers should have and use standardized data collection tools for HIV care and treatment
  • Proper data collection and utilization is important for chronic care management of HIV.
  • Ascertain availability of tools, understanding of indicators, quality of data (accuracy, completeness, timeliness, consistency) as well as evidence of report submission to relevant MOH/oversight persons.
  • For PMTCT, record in ANC booklet. This ensures that HIV care is not overlooked during routine antenatal care visits. It also ensures that the service providers delivering the mother have the information needed for continuity of care for the mother and to prevent HIV infection to the newborn baby.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-340-Care Tx-Was patient offered correct ART drugs as per the national guidelines'
column5: 'Was patient offered correct ART drugs as per the national guidelines'
column6:
'
  • Ensure providers offer ART as per national guidelines and protocols. This is important to ensure optimal response to treatment, standardize care as well as minimize risk of emergence of resistant strains.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-350-Care Tx-Screening for pregnancy at every visit (Female patients )'
column5: 'Screening for pregnancy at every visit (Female patients )'
column6:
'

Rule out pregnancy in female patients during each visit

  • Providers should take proper reproductive history including screening for pregnancy in HIV positive women so as not to miss interventions targeting prevention of mother to child transmission of HIV.
  • HIV positive women should be offered and supported to use dual protection (condoms and an FP method) to avoid any unplanned pregnancies.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-360-Care Tx-RECORD REVIEW - POSITIVE CASES'
column5: 'RECORD REVIEW - POSITIVE CASES'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-370-Care Tx-Vital signs- weight and height taken and BMI calculated at every visit correctly charted'
column5: 'Vital signs- weight and height taken and BMI calculated at every visit correctly charted'
column6:
'

At every visit, measure weight, height, blood pressure, temperature and calculate BMI

  • Check if vital signs are taken at every visit and documented in the patient records. These include-temperature, weight, height, blood pressure and pulse rate.
  • It is important to take vital signs at every visit in order to promptly detect any subtle co-morbidities that may need to be managed accordingly like high temperature that may indicate an underlying infection.
  • BMI is additionally useful in monitoring progress of patient on treatment. Patients who are initially underweight should gain weight when treatment is working and patients whose BMI starts to drop could be having treatment failure or opportunistic infections.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-380-Care Tx- Screening and treatment of TB and /or any presenting OI'
column5: 'Screening and treatment of TB and /or any presenting OI'
column6:
'

Screen for TB and other OIs and document at every visit

  • Check if the provider has filled the TB screening cards at every visit as well as documented screening for other OIs with appropriate management where necessary.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-390-Care Tx- Correct ART regimen given'
column5: 'Correct ART regimen given'
column6:
'

ART regimen and dosage should be appropriate for the individual patient

  • For each patient on ART, check whether the regimen is in line with recommended national guidelines taking into consideration age, co-morbidities, other medication and or response to treatment.
  • Following guidelines helps to optimize on proven and effective regimen as well as reducing risk of drug resistance and treatment failure.
  • Providers should have within quick reach SOPs on nationally recommended ART regimen for different circumstances and refer to these as often as necessary.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-400-Care Tx- Correct schedule for CD4 or VL testing'
column5: 'Correct schedule for CD4 or VL testing'
column6:
'

Send for CD4 and VL testing as per schedule and document results

  • Check whether the recommended guidelines for CD4 count and VL testing have been adhered to and results documented in file.
  • CD4 count is currently recommended for all new patients and to determine eligibility for ART (except in children under 10 and pregnant women).
  • VL is recommended for monitoring response to ART.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-410-Care Tx-Proper clinical management of patients including identification of treatment failure'
column5: 'Proper clinical management of patients including identification of treatment failure'
column6:
'

Manage patients as per guidelines with proper decisions made at each visit based on guidelines and documented

  • Check for documentation that proper history taking, physical exam, clinical & laboratory monitoring, screening for OIs and other recommended support services including sexual reproductive health, adherence counselling, nutrition and psychosocial assessment are provided as per guidelines.
  • Look for evidence of clinical staging and laboratory monitoring for treatment failure at recommended intervals.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-420-Care Tx-Available referral directory Pre- ART lab work-up, CD4 and VL samples'
column5: 'Available referral directory Pre- ART lab work-up, CD4 and VL samples'
column6:
'

Referrals should be documented and feedback mechanism in place for various components of care and treatment

  • All facilities offering only HTC should have clear referral systems for follow up of HIV positive patients with documented evidence of the same including feedback.
  • Where feasible, linkages that minimize patient movement (specimen/sample networking) should be put in place to ensure point of care services are offered to the patients.
  • Providers without clear referral systems should be discouraged from offering HTC and instead advised to refer patients for testing until they have the systems in place.
  • Prior to referral or where care and treatment is available, document all lab results clearly in the patient''s file. These are important for follow up to ensure that complications or treatment failure is detected early by making comparisons with previous lab results.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-430-Care Tx-RECORD REVIEW - POSITIVE CASES - PMCTC'
column5: 'RECORD REVIEW - POSITIVE CASES - PMCTC'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-440-Care Tx-Check HTC for all mothers in the ANC register'
column5: 'Check HTC for all mothers in the ANC register'
column6:
'

HTC should be offered to all pregnant mothers and documented in appropriate registers

  • Check in the ANC register whether all pregnant women have HTC results in the relevant column and discuss with provider any discrepancies.
  • HTC should be offered to all pregnant women and noted in the appropriate documents.
  • Women who decline testing should be encouraged during subsequent visits with appropriate counselling and support messages taking into consideration principle of informed consent prior to HIV testing.
  • Where a woman has not been tested, offer counseling and testing. There should never be a missed opportunity to test a pregnant woman.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-450-Care Tx-Review referral and linkages for positive mothers'
column5: 'Review referral and linkages for positive mothers'
column6:
'

Proper referral for further care and treatment should be documented and feedback mechanism put in place for HIV positive pregnant women

  • All facilities offering only HTC to pregnant women should have clear referral systems for follow up of those testing HIV positive with documented evidence of the same including feedback.
  • Providers without clear referral systems should be discouraged from offering HTC and instead advised to refer patients until they have the systems in place.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-460-Care Tx-Check documented counselling on birth plan'
column5: 'Check documented counselling on birth plan'
column6:
'

Develop and follow individualized birth plans for HIV positive pregnant women
This is important to ensure best outcomes for mother and new born by covering key aspects of the delivery process.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-470-Care Tx-Proper clinical management of patients including identification of treatment failure'
column5: 'Proper clinical management of patients including identification of treatment failure'
column6:
'

Patients should be managed as per guidelines with proper decisions made at each visit based on guidelines and documented

  • Check for documentation that proper history taking, physical exam, clinical & laboratory monitoring, screening for OIs and other recommended support services including adherence counselling, nutrition and psychosocial assessment are provided as per guidelines.
  • Look for evidence of clinical staging and laboratory monitoring for treatment failure at recommended intervals.
  • All pregnant women should be on ART irrespective of their CD4 count.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-480-Care Tx- Check the 4 completion / scheduling of the 4 ANC visits'
column5: 'Check the 4 completion / scheduling of the 4 ANC visits'
column6:
'

HIV positive pregnant women need to follow ANC appointments as per standard guidelines

  • Check the ANC register and mother child booklet where available for the implementation of at least 4 ANC visits for pregnant women and discuss any gaps with the provider
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-490-Care Tx-Available referral directory Pre- ART lab work-up, CD4 and VL samples'
column5: 'Available referral directory Pre- ART lab work-up, CD4 and VL samples'
column6:
'

Referrals should be documented and feedback mechanism in place for various components of care and treatment

  • All facilities offering only HTC to pregnant women should have clear referral systems for follow up of HIV positive patients with documented evidence of the same including feedback.
  • Where feasible, linkages that minimize patient movement (specimen/sample networking) should be put in place to ensure point of care services are offered to the patients.
  • Providers without clear referral systems should be discouraged from offering HTC and instead advised to refer patients until they have the systems in place.
  • Prior to referral or where care and treatment is available, document all lab results clearly in the patient''s file. These are important for follow up to ensure that complications or treatment failure is detected early by making comparisons with previous lab results.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-500-WE-Availability of recommended Testing Kits'
column5: 'Availability of recommended Testing Kits'
column6:
'

You should only use the test kits recommended on the National guidelines. Standardization keeps errors to a minimum.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-510-WE-Availability of SOPs and Protocols/National guidelines'
column5: 'Availability of SOPs and Protocols/National guidelines'
column6:
'

Have SOPs and National guidelines for HIV accessible to staff for use.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-520-WE-Availability of job aids or algorithm for HIV testing'
column5: 'Availability of job aids or algorithm for HIV testing'
column6:
'

Job aids and algorithms provide a quick reference point and ensure standardization when performing the HIV test.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-530-WE-Are there screening tools for TB and opportunistic infections?'
column5: 'Are there screening tools for TB and opportunistic infections?'
column6:
'

These are essential. All HIV patients should be routinely screened for Tuberculosis and other opportunistic infections.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-540-WE-Are drugs available-ARVs, cotrimoxazole and dapsone'
column5: 'Are drugs available-ARVs, cotrimoxazole and dapsone'
column6:
'

ARVs and cotrimoxazole should always be in stock. Dapsone should be available for patients allergic to sulphur based drugs.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HIV-550-END-END OF TAB'
column5: 'END OF TAB'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-100-HTN-Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column5: 'Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column6:
'

Simulated observations often limit assessments to knowledge component only and therefore, real life cases should be utilized as often as possible to ascertain attitudes and practices (problem solving skills) of the providers more so in complex real life scenarios.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-110-HTN-Digital BP Machine'
column5: 'Digital BP Machine'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-120-HTN-Provider introduces him/herself and obtains consent and explains the procedure'
column5: 'Provider introduces him/herself and obtains consent and explains the procedure'
column6:
'

Introduce oneself and explain the procedure with client prior to taking BP measurement

  • Proper introduction taking into consideration verbal and non verbal cues helps to create rapport and keep patient calm.
  • Explaining the procedure and obtaining consent not only ensure we respect the patients rights but also helps to reduce misunderstanding and make the patient comfortable before the procedure.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-130-HTN-Allows patient to rest for 3 to 5 minutes before measurement'
column5: 'Allows patient to rest for 3 to 5 minutes before measurement'
column6:
'

Patient should sit and relax for about 5 minutes before taking BP

  • Any physical activity, mood change and positioning can affect BP readings by between 5-40mmHg.
  • Allowing the patient to rest helps to ensure correct BP readings are obtained.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-140-HTN-BP reading taken according to protocols'
column5: 'BP reading taken according to protocols'
column6:
'

Use the BP machine to take the reading as per protocol
The following help to get an accurate BP reading:

  • Use of correct cuff size
  • Complete exposure of the upper arm
  • Proper positioning of patient seated (arm, back, feet supported and not crossed)
  • Minimal talking and patient comfort
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-150-HTN-Take 2 measurements at least 2 to 3 minutes apart in the same sitting.'
column5: 'Take 2 measurements at least 2 to 3 minutes apart in the same sitting.'
column6:
'

If first reading is high (>140/90), repeat measurement after 2-3 minutes

  • Taking two readings allows us to confirm the first reading and ensure proper management of the patient. Two readings should be taken. if the average is 140/90 mmHg or more, an additional reading should be taken at the end of the consultation for confirmation.
  • Blood pressure should be measured in both arms initially, and the arm with the higher reading used for future measurements. If the difference between the two arms is more than 20 mmHg for systolic pressure or 10 mmHg for diastolic pressure, the patient should be referred to the next level of care for examination for vascular stenosis. Patients with accelerated (malignant) hypertension (blood pressure ≥ 180/110 mmHg with papilloedema or retinal haemorrhages) or suspected secondary hypertension should be referred to the next level immediately.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-160-HTN-BP recording done on relevant form'
column5: 'BP recording done on relevant form'
column6:
'

Document measurement(s) in correct data capture tool

  • Record keeping is primarily important in ensuring proper management of the patient.
  • Lack of proper records may affect decision making and follow up of the patient during subsequent visits.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-170-HTN-Is the classification and staging of HTN correctly done?'
column5: 'Is the classification and staging of HTN correctly done?'
column6:
'

If BP is elevated, classify and stage hypertension as below:
Optimum: Blood pressure <120/80mmHg
Prehypertension: BP 120/80 mmHg- 139/89mmHg
Stage 1 (mild): BP 140/90mmHg -159/99mmHg
Stage 2(Moderate): BP 160/100mmHg -179/109mmHg
Stage 3 (severe): BP >180/110mmHg

  • Correct classification ensures proper patient management.
  • Management may include non-pharmacological interventions mostly around diet and exercise as well as pharmacological management with one or more drugs.
  • Incorrect classification may thus affect the choice of treatment including number and dosage of anti-hypertensive drugs.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-180-HTN-Is the patient informed of his/her blood pressure level?'
column5: 'Is the patient informed of his/her blood pressure level?'
column6:
'

Discuss with patient BP findings immediately

  • Informing patient of his/her blood pressure not only ensures that we respect the patients right to information but enables us to obtain informed consent for further examination and management of the patient.
  • It also improves future compliance to medication and follow up.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-190-Assess-Asks for signs and symptoms of hypertension (headache, fatigue, palpitations, chest pains, blurred vision, irregular heart beat)'
column5: 'Asks for signs and symptoms of hypertension (headache, fatigue, palpitations, chest pains, blurred vision, irregular heart beat)'
column6:
'

Take proper history of other signs and symptoms of hypertension including recurrent headache, fatigue, palpitations, chest pains and blurred vision. Symptoms will depend on the organ affected

  • More often hypertension is asymptomatic but presence of signs and symptoms helps in correct classification/staging of the disease and influences management decision.
  • Hypertension affects multiple organs and presence of additional signs/symptoms of organ damage indicates severity of illness and influences treatment options.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-200-Assess-Asks for family history, lifestyle, occupation and any other relevant history.'
column5: 'Asks for family history, lifestyle, occupation and any other relevant history.'
column6:
'

Ask about family history of hypertension, lifestyle (diet & exercise) and occupation

  • Evidence shows that hypertension is associated with other risk factors like family history of hypertension, sedentary lifestyles, smoking, poor stress management, and poor diet.
  • Getting history on these risk factors is necessary in ensuring that part of the patient management includes modification of the risk factors amenable to change at individual level.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-210-Assess-Calculates Body Mass Index- BMI'
column5: 'Calculates Body Mass Index- BMI'
column6:
'

Take height and weight measurement and calculate Body Mass Index (BMI)

  • BMI=weight (kg)/height (m2)
  • BMI is a useful epidemiological measure of obesity. Obesity is a risk factor for hypertension and individuals with BMI higher than 25 have been shown to have an increased risk of hypertension.
  • Calculating the BMI helps to incorporate non-pharmacological management including dietary and lifestyle modifications into the treatment plan of hypertensive patients.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-220-Assess-Physical examination and assessment of presence of target organ damage'
column5: 'Physical examination and assessment of presence of target organ damage'
column6:
'

Obtain consent and conduct full physical exam taking note of any end organ damage.

  • Hypertension affects multiple organs including kidneys, brain, heart and eyes.
  • Proper physical examination ensures we are able to detect organ involvement/damage and manage as appropriate
column7: ascertain whether patient is at risk for heart disease and stroke
column8:
and rule out secondary causes of hypertension.
  • A physical examination should include:
    • Examination of the cardiovascular system, particularly for heart size, evidence of heart failure, evidence of disease in the carotid, renal and peripheral arteries, and physical signs suggestive of coarctation of the aorta, particularly in young people with hypertension
column9:
• Examination for features of secondary hypertension (phaeochromocytoma, Cushing syndrome,etc.)
  • Examination of the lungs for congestion
column10: • Examination of the abdomen for bruits, enlarged kidneys and other masses

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-230-Assess-Conduct baseline investigations- urine dipstick, blood glucose, FBC, Others'
column5: 'Conduct baseline investigations- urine dipstick, blood glucose, FBC, Others'
column6:
'

Discuss with the client, obtain consent and collect blood and urine for the relevant baseline tests, depending on available resources

  • Baseline investigations help us to confirm end organ involvement that has an impact on patient treatment
  • The baseline investigations include:
    • Urea/electrolyte and creatinine
    • Lipid profiles
    • Electrocardiograph (ECG)
    • Chest X ray
    • Urine dipstick
    • Fasting Blood Sugar

Impaired renal function for example may influence choice of antihypertensive drugs and dosages. Other baseline investigations help to rule out co-morbidities like diabetes that need to be concurrently managed
column7:
and also help in patient follow up.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-240-Assess-Do proper risk profiling- average, low added, moderately added, high added or very high added)'
column5: 'Do proper risk profiling- average, low added, moderately added, high added or very high added)'
column6:
'

Conduct risk profile based on additional history/clinical findings

  • Risk profiling help to make a decisions on how to individualize treatment and follow up. WHO/ISH risk profiles are available by geographic area and should be used in determining risk of 10-year future cardiac event based patient history, risk factors and clinical profile.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-250-Diag_Mgmt-Proper diagnosis made based on BP readings and risk profiling'
column5: 'Proper diagnosis made based on BP readings and risk profiling'
column6:
'

Based on BP readings and risk profile, make diagnosis and classify hypertension

  • Proper diagnosis helps to ensure the correct mix of interventions will have the desired outcome for the patient.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-260-Diag_Mgmt-Correct drug therapy as per diagnosis and guidelines'
column5: 'Correct drug therapy as per diagnosis and guidelines'
column6:
'

Prescribe medication according to classification and in line with national guidelines and consistent supply of prescribed medication
Correct drug therapy ensures that the blood pressure is brought under control within a reasonable time frame and with minimal side effects to the patient.

  • Use of low dose combination therapy helps to minimize drug toxicities while ensuring optimal blood pressure control.

Recommended drug regimen is as below:

  • Low dose aspirin 75mg once daily if aged more than 50 years and aspirin is not contraindicated
  • Counsel on lifestyle modification including diet, importance of regular cardiovascular exercise, cessation of smoking, moderation of alcohol etc.

Stage 1 (mild): BP 140/90mmHg -159/99mmHg

  • Monotherapy:
  • Preferably with hydrochlorothiazide
  • For diabetics an Angiotensin Converting Enzyme(ACE) Inhibitor such as enalapril is preferred

Stage 2 (Moderate): BP 160/100mmHg -179/109mmHg

  • Use Combination therapy with
  • with hydrochlorothiazide + beta blocker or ACE inhibitor
  • Beta blockers are contraindicated in patients with asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
  • Specialist review

Stage 3 (severe): BP >180/110mmHg

  • Admit in a tertiary facility
  • Emergency measures: Nifedipine 20mg orally repeated after one hour OR Hydralazine 10mg IV every 15 minutes.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-270-Diag_Mgmt-Counsels client on lifestyle modification instructions and treatment adherence and follow up date based on clients BP levels and condition'
column5: 'Counsels client on lifestyle modification instructions and treatment adherence and follow up date based on clients BP levels and condition'
column6:
'

Discuss and counsel client on treatment plan including lifestyle modification, adherence to medication and follow up appointments

  • Risk factors for hypertension include poor diet, sedentary lifestyles, smoking and highly stressful jobs. Modification of these risk factors on its own leads to reduction in blood pressure and augments pharmacological intervention in hypertensive patients.
  • Adherence to treatment ensures that the medication can reach steady concentrations in the blood that are able to lower the blood pressure.
  • Giving follow up dates dependent on assessment of patient allows us to closely monitor effect of treatment and adjust accordingly.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-280-Diag_Mgmt-Client referral- right client referred according to protocol and well documented'
column5: 'Client referral- right client referred according to protocol and well documented'
column6:
'

Discuss with patient the need for a multi-disciplinary approach to management including nutritionists, clinicians and refer accordingly

  • Hypertension is a progressive disease so prompt referral based on individual assessment helps to minimize delays in diagnosis and treatment thus ensuring better outcomes.
  • Patients with co-morbidities/higher risk profiles may require referrals due to complex nature of their treatment.
  • Good documentation helps the receiving site to appropriately manage the patient and ensures proper follow up at primary site.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-290-WE-Is there a functioning BP machine?'
column5: 'Is there a functioning BP machine?'
column6:
'

A BP machine is the most important equipment for diagnosis and follow -up of hypertension. Take BP readings for hypertensive patients during all visits.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-300-WE-Is there a functioning weighing scale?'
column5: 'Is there a functioning weighing scale?'
column6:
'

A functioning weighing scale is needed to take weight of hypertensive patients and calculate the BMI.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-310-WE-Are antihypertensive drugs available?'
column5: 'Are antihypertensive drugs available?'
column6:
'

Always have antihypertensive drugs for proper management of patients with hypertension.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-320-WE-Are urine dip sticks, blood glucose strips available?'
column5: 'Are urine dip sticks, blood glucose strips available?'
column6:
'

These are necessary for testing for presence of diabetes and kidney damage which frequently occur with hypertension.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS HYP-330-END-END OF TAB'
column5: 'END OF TAB'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-100-Licenses-Facility registration'
column5: 'Facility registration'
column6:
'

Register and display the facility registration
It is illegal to run an unlicensed health facility. Comply with your country''s regulator requirements. The license should also be renewed on time and should be displayed prominently.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-110-Licenses-Professional license (doctors, nurses/midwives, Chews etc.)'
column5: 'Professional license (doctors, nurses/midwives, Chews etc.)'
column6:
'

Ensure all clinical service providers are licensed
Only licensed staff are allowed to attend to patients or perform clinical procedures. This is to ensure safety of the patients.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-120-GIE-Clean and hygienic surfaces (walls, floors etc.)'
column5: 'Clean and hygienic surfaces (walls, floors etc.)'
column6:
'

The facility should be cleaned as needed on daily basis
Management needs to provide cleaning supplies that enable staff to routinely clean surfaces to ensure the health-care environment is visibly clean and free from dust and soil. The workers tasked with this duty should perform it thoroughly and their supervisor should ensure so.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-130-GIE-Running water and soap in critical points (toilet, examination room, lab, patient waiting area)'
column5: 'Running water and soap in critical points (toilet, examination room, lab, patient waiting area)'
column6:
'

Avail clean running water and soap at critical points

  • Frequent hand-washing is the most effective means of reducing the spread of organisms.
  • When running water and soap are far from patient care areas, staff and patients are less likely to wash their hands as required.
  • Drying hands on reusable towels is a means of transmitting germs, therefore disposable or non-reusable towels should be used.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-140-GIE-Adequate lighting'
column5: 'Adequate lighting'
column6:
'

The hospital design should allow for as much natural light as possible

  • Electricity should also be available if possible to enable use of examination or operating lights to illuminate the area of on the patient''s body during a procedure.
  • If operating critical services like an operating theatre, then a functional back up generator must be available to power machines and to provide lighting.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-150-GIE-Adequate storage for drugs, consumables and commodities'
column5: 'Adequate storage for drugs, consumables and commodities'
column6:
'

Create/build adequate storage area

The facility should have adequate storage space for supplies and equipment. Apart from adequate storage, the following are other general principles when creating and organizing a storage area.

  • It should be secure to prevent theft : burglar proofing windows, security locks on doors etc.
  • Access should be restricted to authorized personnel only.
  • Storage areas should be of sufficient capacity to allow the orderly storage of the various categories of materials and products.
  • Temperature should be controlled and the store should be protected from excessive humidity.
  • Should have adequate lighting.
  • Should be clean and free from pests.
  • Should allow for separate section for hazardous or flammable supplies.
  • Should be well organized to allow easy access or commodities.
  • Items should be arranged to enable dispatch to users based on FEFO principle.
  • Good documentation and record keeping.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-160-GIE-Functional Internal and/or external toilets'
column5: 'Functional Internal and/or external toilets'
column6:
'

Adequate and functional latrines/toilets

  • Have separate facilities for male, female and children.
  • Have separate toilets/latrines for staff and patients.
  • Have adequate number of toilets depending on the number of patients served.
  • They should be clean.
  • Have a clear sign for ease of access.
  • Toilets should have water for flushing while latrines should have covers.
  • Design to respond to local cultural or social conditions (e.g. provide water for anal washing)
  • Equip them to enable ease of use by disabled people, the elderly, pregnant women and the very sick.
  • Provide running water and soap at the exit.
  • Minimize risk of potential violence (including sexual violence) e.g. by having locks inside and having lights for use at night.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-170-GIE-Are services offered in a confidential space?'
column5: 'Are services offered in a confidential space?'
column6:
'

Service provision areas should provide visual and auditory privacy
Confidentiality is every patient''s right and it is the duty of the service provider to ensure the space for service provision offers the patient confidentiality.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-180-GIE-Approved waste collection and disposal method'
column5: 'Approved waste collection and disposal method'
column6:
'

Have a waste management plan for waste collection and disposal
Hospital waste is a reservoir of pathogenic micro-organisms and requires appropriate, safe and reliable handling. Approved waste management systems and disposal sites is a requirement for licensing of health facilities. This is essential for infection prevention and ensuring safety to you and others.
Ensure you:

  • Establish systems and infrastructure for waste management.
  • Develop and disseminate standards and guidelines on waste management.
  • Promote continuous professional development for health workers on waste management.
  • Train waste handlers on proper waste management.
  • Promote segregation, storage, collection, pre-treatment, transportation and proper disposal of waste.
  • Provide adequate resources to increase efficiency in waste management.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-190-GIE-An established inventory management system in use'
column5: 'An established inventory management system in use'
column6:
'

Have an inventory management system
The purpose of an inventory system is to:

  • Allow preparation of effective orders
  • Maintain sufficient stock levels within the budget limits
  • Maintain records according to local requirements
  • Enable adjustment of stock levels depending on morbidity trends
  • Prevent expiry of medicines
  • Provide appropriate, safe and secure storage

Benefits of inventory management system:

  • Prevents Stock Outs--Sufficient stock levels ensures supplies are available for patient care.
  • Ensures supplies are delivered at intervals which saves on administrative time and costs.
  • Increase patients'' confidence when they know hospital has supplies.
  • Ensures there is accountability for commodities.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-200-GIE-Infection prevention equipments'
column5: 'Infection prevention equipments'
column6:
'

For infection prevention in a hospital the following commodities should be available:

  • Soap
  • Clean running water
  • Different colors of waste bags for proper waste segregation
  • Sharps containers
  • Cotton wool/alcohol swabs
  • Sodium hypochlorite
  • Sterilization equipment etc.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-210-GIE-Availability of Designated room for services'
column5: 'Availability of Designated room for services'
column6:
'

Allocate rooms for services

  • To ensure easy patient flow, rooms should be designated for specific services.
  • Designating rooms also helps infection prevention (e.g. surgical procedures should be done in a minor theatre/procedure room rather than the consultation room).
  • Patient confidentiality can be maintained.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-220-GIE-Availability of referral network and identified referral site'
column5: 'Availability of referral network and identified referral site'
column6:
'

An effective referral system ensures a close relationship between all levels of the health system and helps patients receive the best possible care.

  • Referral protocols should be developed and made available to all service providers.
  • The referral system must be open to revision based on practical experience, and in order to meet the goals of the health system overall.
  • Periodically review functionality of the referral system.
  • Ensure feedback mechanisms to track outcomes of the referred patients.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-230-GIE-Patient record cards and forms'
column5: 'Patient record cards and forms'
column6:
'

Patient record cards /forms are important for documenting a patient''s notes. This is critical for follow up, continuity of care and for data audits.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-240-GIE-Registers'
column5: 'Registers'
column6:
'

Have all the required registers to capture data. Data forms the basis of all decision making processes.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-250-GIE-Availability of IEC materials'
column5: 'Availability of IEC materials'
column6:
'

IEC materials are aimed at changing or reinforcing health-related behaviors in a target audience through information, education, and communication.
The IEC materials should:

  • Have a clear objective to change or reinforce a specific behavior.
  • Target a specific audience (e.g., mothers of children below five years old).
  • Address a specific problem rather than multiple problems at one time.(e.g., offering increased fluids and continuing feeding a child with diarrhea.)
  • Set a timeframe within which the behavior change is expected to occur.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-260-GIE-Evidence of Demand generation activities'
column5: 'Evidence of Demand generation activities'
column6:
'

Plan demand creating activities

  • Community mobilization activities and advertising campaigns should target specific groups.
  • Inform the target population of the services offered at the clinic.
  • Specific efforts should be made to overcome barriers between community members and uptake of services.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-270-GIE-Availability of SOPs and Protocols/National guidelines'
column5: 'Availability of SOPs and Protocols/National guidelines'
column6:
'

National guidelines and SOPs should be available for service providers

  • National guidelines are rigorously developed using evidence-based medicine criteria and consist of detailed instructions for the application of that evidence to patient care, ensuring the highest possible quality of care is given to a patient.
  • SOPs are systematically developed statements that assist decisions about appropriate health care for specific circumstances. They are more specific than guidelines and are defined in greater detail. They provide a comprehensive set of rigid criteria outlining the management steps for a single clinical condition or aspects of the health facility.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-280-SDGs-Infection Prevention Protocol'
column5: 'Infection Prevention Protocol'
column6:
'

Have documented infection prevention protocol
This should be available to all staff as each individual is responsible for infection prevention.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-290-Commodities-Antibiotics – parenteral and oral'
column5: 'Antibiotics – parenteral and oral'
column6:
'

Have parenteral and oral antibiotics
Antibiotics are some of the most essential drugs in a health facility. Availability of antibiotics is part of the assessment of a health facility''s readiness for operation.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-300-Commodities-Intravenous fluids'
column5: 'Intravenous fluids'
column6:
'

Intravenous fluids are essential for management of various conditions, including dehydration, hemorrhage, shock. However, they should only be given providers allowed to administer intravenous injections.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-310-Commodities-Are the commodities properly secured and stored according to guidelines'
column5: 'Are the commodities properly secured and stored according to guidelines'
column6:
'

Commodities should be kept in a store to ensure safety, control and availability when needed.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-320-Doc-Data quality assurance checks'
column5: 'Data quality assurance checks'
column6:
'

Data quality assurance should be done periodically

  • The hospital data should be available for internal and external quality assurance.
  • Areas of weakness should be identified for improvement.
  • Feedback should be given to the staff to ensure there is improvement in quality of care.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS WE-330-END-END OF TAB'
column5: 'END OF TAB'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-100-Intro-Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-100-Intro-Is this a real or simul'
column5: 'Is this a real or simulated observation?'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-110-Intro-Provider obtains personal history (incl name, age)'
column5: 'Provider obtains personal history (incl name, age)'
column6:
'
  • Name: identification/record keeping.
  • Age: determine drug doses, nutritional status, and growth evaluation.
  • Address: determine if high risk area for certain diseases (e.g. Malaria).
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-120-Intro-Provider asks reason for visiting health facility'
column5: 'Provider asks reason for visiting health facility'
column6:
'

Determine patient complaints

  • Initial visit or follow-up.
  • Initial visit: assess and treat.
  • Follow-up visit: assess and advise to complete medication, change medication or refer.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-130-Inq-Provider asks for duration and pattern of fever.'
column5: 'Provider asks for duration and pattern of fever.'
column6:
'

The most common cause of fever is an infection which may be localized or systemic
column7:
other causes include malignancy, allergic reaction, and inflammatory disorders. In malaria endemic areas, fever without focal signs is commonly due to malaria.
Determine duration of fever: ask when the fever started.
Pattern of fever: Periodic fevers occurring every 48-72 hours may occur in malaria depending on the species, but may not always occur in falciparum malaria. In typhoid fever, the fever rises in a step-wise manner.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-140-Inq-Asks for associated symptoms: chills/rigors, headache, joint pains, loss of appetite, nausea'
column5: 'Asks for associated symptoms: chills/rigors, headache, joint pains, loss of appetite, nausea'
column6:
'

Ask for associated symptoms

  • Chills and/or rigors: The classic pattern of malaria begins with a period of chills/rigors which last for about 1-2 hours then followed by fever.
  • Some of the other symptoms of malaria include headaches, muscle aches, joint pains, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pains.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-150-Inq-Asks for danger signs and symptoms of severe malaria'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-150-Inq-Asks for danger signs and symp'
column5: 'Asks for danger signs and symptoms of severe malaria'
column6:
'

Danger signs and signs of severe malaria include:

  • Impaired consciousness (including unarousable coma), change in behaviour
column7: • Prostration, i.e. generalized weakness so that the patient is unable to sit, stand or walk without assistance
column12: • Reduced amount of urine or not passing urine

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-160-Inq-Asks for other symptoms that could indicate other focus of infection: cough, painful urination, painful ear, stiff neck, diarrhoea'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-160-Inq-Asks for other symptoms t'
column5: 'Asks for other symptoms that could indicate other focus of infection: cough, painful urination, painful ear, stiff neck, diarrhoea'
column6:
'

Ask for other symptoms that could indicate other focus of infection:

  • Cough, difficult breathing

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-170-Inq-Provider asks for medication history including antimalarials for this illness'
column5: 'Provider asks for medication history including antimalarials for this illness'
column6:
'

Medication history

  • Determine if patient has received any treatment for this illness, including antimalarials.
  • Consider possibility of incompletely treated disease or drug resistance.
  • Find out if the patient is on any other medication for other illness, whether long term or short term.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-180-Inq-Provider asks about prior testing for malaria during this illness'
column5: 'Provider asks about prior testing for malaria during this illness'
column6:
'

Determine if the patient has been tested for malaria during this illness and what the results were. This will help in identification of a correct treatment plan.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-190-Inq-Provider asks about the patient''s HIV status'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-190-Inq-Provider asks about the p'
column5: 'Provider asks about the patient''s HIV status'
column6:
'

HIV-infected adults are at increased risk of severe malaria and death.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-200-PE-Provider checks for danger signs/signs of severe malaria'
column5: 'Provider checks for danger signs/signs of severe malaria'
column6:
'

Check for danger signs/signs of severe malaria

  • Impaired consciousness: Glasgow coma scale < 11

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-210-PE-Provider determines the patient''s temperature'
column5: 'Provider determines the patient''s temperature'
column6:
'
  • Measure the patient''s temperature to determine presence of fever.
  • Fever is elevated body temperature of more than 38°C if measured centrally (ear, rectal, or oral) or 37.5°C axillary.
  • Remember that the temperature might be normal at that particular moment if the patient has taken antipyretics.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-220-PE-Takes vital signs: Blood pressure, pulse rate and respiratory rate'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-220-PE-Takes vital signs: Blood p'
column5: 'Takes vital signs: Blood pressure, pulse rate and respiratory rate'
column6:
'

Take other vital signs to determine patient stability

  • Blood pressure
  • Respiratory rate
  • Pulse rate
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-230-PE-Checks for pallor, jaundice'
column5: 'Checks for pallor, jaundice'
column6:
'

Severe malaria causes anaemia and jaundice due to hemolysis of red blood cells

  • Check for pallor on the conjunctiva, palms or tongue.
  • Check for jaundice on the sclera (white part of eye) using natural light.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-240-PE-Performs physical examination of all systems'
column5: 'Performs physical examination of all systems'
column6:
'

Examine the patient thoroughly paying attention to sites of possible infection:
General examination: skin lesions, including rash
column8:
nutritional status (wasting).
Head and neck: neck pain or stiffness
column9: throat, tonsils, ears for inflammation and discharge
column11:
mouth (Koplik''s spots, ulcers or lesions).
Chest: difficult breathing
column16:
murmurs,
Abdominal or genitourinary: enlarged liver or spleen
column20:
rectal and vaginal examination for pain, discharge, ulcers, mass.
Muscles and joints: red, hot, swollen, painful joint(s) with reduced mobility
column21: swollen, painful limb (deep venous thrombosis, cellulitis)

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-250-PE-Provider takes blood sample for malaria rapid diagnostic test or microscopy in the lab'
column5: 'Provider takes blood sample for malaria rapid diagnostic test or microscopy in the lab'
column6:
'
  • Parasitological diagnosis of malaria must be confirmed using Rapid Diagnostic Testing (RDT) or microscopy in the laboratory before giving any antimalarial.
  • Giving antimalarial without testing leads to unnecessary use of ACTs which is expensive
column7: may lead to early ACT resistance
column8: and leads to delay in investigating the patient for the real cause of fever.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-260-RDT-Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-260-RDT-Is this a real or simulat'
column5: 'Is this a real or simulated observation?'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-270-RDT-Assembles new test packet, swab, buffer, pipette, lancet and gloves'
column5: 'Assembles new test packet, swab, buffer, pipette, lancet and gloves'
column6:
'
  • Saves time by avoiding unnecessary movements looking for supplies after starting the procedure.
  • Reduces the risk of sharps injuries caused by reaching out for objects.
  • Ensures there is no movement during the test procedure that might prolong the time for performing the test leading to inaccurate results.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-280-RDT-Puts a new pair of gloves'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-280-RDT-Puts a new pair of gloves'
column5: 'Puts a new pair of gloves'
column6:
'
  • Gloves will protect you and the patient from contracting blood-borne diseases such as HIV, Hepatitis B among others.
  • A new pair of gloves will protect the second patient from exposure to infections from the first patient.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-290-RDT-(i) Checks expiry date on package (ii) checks desiccant sachet is still dry (iii) Write''s patient''s name or ID on cassette (iv) Places cassette on a level surface'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-290-RDT-(i) Checks expiry date on'
column5: '(i) Checks expiry date on package (ii) checks desiccant sachet is still dry (iii) Write''s patient''s name or ID on cassette (iv) Places cassette on a level surface'
column6:
'

(i) Always check the expiry date on the RDT package-an expired RDT kit will give incorrect results.

(ii) Check if desiccant sachet is dry-A wet desiccant means the RDT has been exposed to excessive moisture and therefore is damaged. A damaged RDT will give incorrect results.

(iii) Always write the patient''s name or ID on cassette- This will avoid mix up of results with other patients'' and prevents giving a patient incorrect results.

(iv) Place cassette on a level surface- a tilted surface will interfere with the lateral flow of blood and buffer during the test and will result in incorrect results.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-300-RDT-Cleans finger with antiseptic/ alcohol'
column5: 'Cleans finger with antiseptic/ alcohol'
column6:
'

Antiseptic/alcohol kills bacteria on the finger surface. This prevents introduction of infection into the tissues when pricking the finger to obtain a blood sample.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-310-RDT-Allows finger to dry before pricking it'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-310-RDT-Allows finger to dry befo'
column5: 'Allows finger to dry before pricking it'
column6:
'

Alcohol/antiseptic hemolyses blood. Hemolysed blood will not give correct results and will lead to misdiagnosis.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-320-RDT-Use a sterile lancet for finger pricking'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-320-RDT-Use a sterile lancet for'
column5: 'Use a sterile lancet for finger pricking'
column6:
'

Prevents cross-infecting a patient with blood borne diseases such as HIV or Hepatitis B from a contaminated lancet.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-330-RDT-Puncture the side of the ball of the finger'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-330-RDT-Puncture the side of the'
column5: 'Puncture the side of the ball of the finger'
column6:
'

A puncture to the side of the ball of the finger is less painful than a puncture to the finger tip.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-340-RDT-Provider disposes of lancet in sharps bin immediately after pricking finger'
column5: 'Provider disposes of lancet in sharps bin immediately after pricking finger'
column6:
'

Prevents accidental sharps injuries to you and others which may occur if lancets are not disposed of immediately.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-350-RDT-Collect blood with the enclosed pipette making sure to fill close to the first cross line'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-350-RDT-Collect blood with the en'
column5: 'Collect blood with the enclosed pipette making sure to fill close to the first cross line'
column6:
'

Using the enclosed pipette ensures the correct amount of blood is collected. Using too little or too much blood can cause the test kit to give an incorrect result.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-360-RDT-Using a pipette, blots blood onto the pad in the correct well'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-360-RDT-Using a pipette, blots bl'
column5: 'Using a pipette, blots blood onto the pad in the correct well'
column6:
'
  • Putting blood into the wrong well will give incorrect results.
  • For test accuracy, blood needs to reach and be absorbed by the pad at the bottom of the well.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-370-RDT-Disposes of the used pipette in the sharps container immediately after use'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-370-RDT-Disposes of the used pipe'
column5: 'Disposes of the used pipette in the sharps container immediately after use'
column6:
'

Dispose of used pipette into the sharps container immediately after use to prevent contamination of surfaces and transmission of blood borne diseases.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-380-RDT-Dispense correct number of drops of the buffer into the correct well'
column5: 'Dispense correct number of drops of the buffer into the correct well'
column6:
'

The test will not work correctly if too much or too little buffer is added. Adding buffer in the wrong well will also give in an invalid result.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-390-RDT-Wait correct time before reading results'
column5: 'Wait correct time before reading results'
column6:
'

Read the results within the specified time
Reading the results before or after the recommended time will result in interpretation of incorrect results.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-400-RDT-Read the test results correctly'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-400-RDT-Read the test results cor'
column5: 'Read the test results correctly'
column6:
'

If you do not read results correctly, the patient will not get the correct treatment. Understand what each line means:

  • Line at Control Line position AND Line at Test Line position = Positive (the result is positive even if the test line is very faint)
  • Line at Control Line and NO LINE at Test Line position = negative
  • No line at Control Line position BUT line at Test Line = invalid
  • No line at Control Line position AND NO LINE at Test Line position = invalid

A control line must be present for the result to be valid but the control line does not prove that the RDT result is accurate.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-410-RDT-Record results in the register'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-410-RDT-Record results in the reg'
column5: 'Record results in the register'
column6:
'
  • Recording results immediately ensures they are not forgotten.
  • Ensures records will be available for patient follow up, tracking treatment responses, forecasting and planning for commodities.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-420-RDT-Dispose gloves, wrappers, alcohol swab and desiccant safely'
column5: 'Dispose gloves, wrappers, alcohol swab and desiccant safely'
column6:
'

Proper waste segregation at source and disposal ensures infection prevention and safety to you and others.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-430-RDT-Explains the results to the patient'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-430-RDT-Explains the results to t'
column5: 'Explains the results to the patient'
column6:
'

Explain the test results to the patient
An informed patient is more likely to adhere to treatment and to take preventive measures to reduce risks of getting malaria again.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-440-RDT-Should RDT have been undertaken based on symptoms'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-440-RDT-Should RDT have been unde'
column5: 'Should RDT have been undertaken based on symptoms'
column6:
'

Perform RDT only for suspected malaria cases to avoid wastage of resources and delayed diagnosis. Undertake for:

  • A patient with fever in a high malaria risk area.
  • A patient with fever and history of travel to high risk malaria area in the last 2 weeks.
  • A patient with fever and no other symptoms indicative of any other illness in a low risk area.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-450-DxTx-Does the provider diagnose the illness correctly?'
column5: 'Does the provider diagnose the illness correctly?'
column6: 'Fever in Adults: Diagnosis and Treatment Matrix'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-460-DxTx-Does the provider administer the correct treatment?'
column5: 'Does the provider administer the correct treatment?'
column6: 'Fever in Adults: Diagnosis and Treatment Matrix'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-470-Counseling-Provider explains the treatment to be given'
column5: 'Provider explains the treatment to be given'
column6:
'

Explain the treatment to the patient to improve compliance.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-480-Counseling-Provider counsels on proper dosage (no. of doses/days, side effects)'
column5: 'Provider counsels on proper dosage (no. of doses/days, side effects)'
column6:
'

Counsel on proper dosage

  • Counsel on specific doses per day, total number of days of treatment, and potential side effects
column7: including severe side effects that require a return visit to hospital.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-490-Counseling-Provider advises referral if condition worsens or refers in case of severe illness'
column5: 'Provider advises referral if condition worsens or refers in case of severe illness'
column6:
'
  • A patient with severe illness should be admitted/referred after stabilization and administration of pre-referral treatment.
  • Advice the patient on referral in case he/she worsens.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-500-WE-Adequate water supply (sufficient for outlet operations)'
column5: 'Adequate water supply (sufficient for outlet operations)'
column6:
'

For infection prevention, ensure adequate water is available for:

  • Hand washing before and after procedures
  • Cleaning work place
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-510-WE-Adequate lighting (sufficient for reading test)'
column5: 'Adequate lighting (sufficient for reading test)'
column6:
'

Provide adequate lighting for RDT procedure area
Good light is needed to be able to read the test results correctly. In conditions of poor lighting, one may not see the test lines clearly or a faint positive may be missed.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-520-WE-Space for conducting RDT (confidentiality)'
column5: 'Space for conducting RDT (confidentiality)'
column6:
'

Provide adequate space for conducting RDT

  • There should be adequate space to allow client confidentiality and both visual and auditory privacy.
  • Adequate space to perform the test reduces the risk of sustaining sharps injuries.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-530-WE-Presence of job aids'
column5: 'Presence of job aids'
column6:
'

Have job aids and display them prominently
Job aids act as quick reference points and provide standardize procedures for the provider.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-540-WE-RDTs stored in a dry place away from direct sunlight'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-540-WE-RDTs stored in a dry place'
column5: 'RDTs stored in a dry place away from direct sunlight'
column6:
'

RDTs are sensitive to heat
If subjected to hot conditions above those stated by the manufacturer, the RDTs will lose sensitivity before the expiry date indicated on the package.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-550-WE-Alcohol, Lancets, Gloves'
column5: 'Alcohol, Lancets, Gloves'
column6:
'

To perform RDT procedure safely, have:

  • Alcohol for swabbing finger-prick sites
  • Sterile lancets to prevent cross-infections
  • Gloves to reduce risk of exposure to potentially infectious material
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-560-WE-Timers, lead/grease pencils, marker pens'
column5: 'Timers, lead/grease pencils, marker pens'
column6:
'

Have timers and a pen that can write on the RDT cassette

  • Timers needed to set the time when test is ready for reading.
  • Marker pens or grease pencils needed to label the patient''s RDT kit to prevent a mix-up with other patients'' test kits.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-570-WE-Biohazard waste bags'
column5: 'Biohazard waste bags'
column6:
'

Needed for proper waste disposal for infection prevention

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-580-WE-Cotton wool, Disinfectants, Soap'
column5: 'Cotton wool, Disinfectants, Soap'
column6:
'

These are needed for infection prevention.

  • Cotton wool to swab fingers with alcohol
  • Disinfectants for decontaminating equipment and work surfaces.
  • Soap for hand washing and cleaning the work environment.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-590-WE-Sharps container'
column5: 'Sharps container'
column6:
'

To safely dispose of sharps immediately after use to avoid injuries to patients, health providers and cleaners.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-600-WE-Quality assured RDTs in stock on day of visit'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-600-WE-Quality assured RDTs in st'
column5: 'Quality assured RDTs in stock on day of visit'
column6:
'

Quality assured RDTs should always be in stock for immediate testing and appropriate treatment.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-610-WE-Expired RDTs in stock on day of visit'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-610-WE-Expired RDTs in stock on d'
column5: 'Expired RDTs in stock on day of visit'
column6:
'
  • Adhere to First-to-expire first-out (FEFO) procedures when dispatching RDTs from the store to the provider.
  • Establish policy and procedure to manage short -expiry RDTs.
  • Avoid overstocking.
  • Do proper forecasting to avoid wastage.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-620-WE-RDTs stock out for MORE THAN 1 WEEK / 7 days in the past 3 months'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-620-WE-RDTs stock out for MORE TH'
column5: 'RDTs stock out for MORE THAN 1 WEEK / 7 days in the past 3 months'
column6:
'

Stock out data is critical for monitoring supply chain performance and highlighting supply gaps that may be present.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-630-WE-Quality assured ACTs in stock'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-630-WE-Quality assured ACTs in st'
column5: 'Quality assured ACTs in stock'
column6:
'

Quality assured ACTs should always be in stock to ensure that all confirmed cases of malaria are started on ACTs immediately, reducing risk of complications and death.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-640-WE-Expired Quality Assured ACTs in stock on day of visit'
column5: 'Expired Quality Assured ACTs in stock on day of visit'
column6:
'
  • Never dispense an expired drug, it will not work and may cause harm to the patient.
  • Adhere to First-to-expire first-out (FEFO) procedures-always dispatch the first to expire ACTs from the store to the provider to avoid ACTs expiring on shelf.
  • Establish policy and procedure to manage short -expiry ACTs.
  • Order long-expiry ACTs.
  • Do not overstock.
  • Do proper forecasting to avoid wastage.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-650-WE-Logbook/register/record book is present at the outlet'
column5: 'Logbook/register/record book is present at the outlet'
column6:
'

Record books serve as reference points and are source documents for patient follow up, quality assurance visits, disease surveillance and are sources of data for report writing.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-660-WE-The patients details are recorded and organised in legible manner, including date of test is recorded'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-660-WE-The patients details are r'
column5: 'The patients details are recorded and organised in legible manner, including date of test is recorded'
column6:
'

Write legibly, record all patient details including full name, age and date to ensure validity of data for decision making and planning purposes.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-670-WE-Results of the tests are recorded/if not test action taken is recorded'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-670-WE-Results of the tests are r'
column5: 'Results of the tests are recorded/if not test action taken is recorded'
column6:
'

The number of tests performed and results guides the estimation of stocks to be ordered and provides data for analysis during quality assurance assessments of RDTs.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-680-WE-Reports for the weeks preceding the assessment have been submitted'
column4: 'NG HNQIS MA-680-WE-Reports for the weeks prec'
column5: 'Reports for the weeks preceding the assessment have been submitted'
column6:
'

Regular and timely submission of reports enables morbidity surveillance and procurement planning resulting in timely resupply of commodities for diagnosis and treatment.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS MA-690-END-END OF TAB'
column5: 'END OF TAB'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-100-Assess-Assess patient for shock and other life-threatening conditions'
column5: 'Assess patient for shock and other life-threatening conditions'
column6:
'

Before performing uterine evacuation, any serious medical conditions that are present should be addressed immediately. Assess the woman for life threatening conditions. These include:

  • shock,
  • acute abdomen,
  • sepsis,
  • cervical or pelvic infection,
  • hemorrhage,
  • signs of manipulation (uterine perforation, vaginal or cervical laceration, abdominal injury)

Some of these complications may occur with incomplete or clandestine abortions. Uterine evacuation is often an important component of definitive management in these cases and once the patient is stabilized, the procedure should not be delayed.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-110-Assess-If any complications are identified, stabilizes patient and refers if necessary'
column5: 'If any complications are identified, stabilizes patient and refers if necessary'
column6:
'

Sepsis/Shock- Emergency Assessment

  1. Rapid initial assessment for shock if woman appears to be frankly hemorrhagic, losing consciousness, near collapse, septic, etc.
  2. Call for help
  3. Check vital signs (blood pressure, pulse, temperature, respiratory rate)
  4. Evaluate for the following signs of shock:
    • Fast, weak pulse (rate > 110 beats per minute)
    • Low blood pressure (diastolic < 60)
    • Pallor (generally very pale, pallor of palms or around the mouth)
    • Sweatiness
    • Rapid breathing (respiration > 30 per minute)
    • Anxiousness, confusion or unconsciousness
    • Frank, profuse hemorrhage
  5. If the woman is in shock or clinically unstable:
    • If woman is conscious or family member is present, find out: current medications, serious health condition, known allergies, if she ingested any substance to induce abortion other than misoprostol or attempted mechanical dilation with unsafe provider.
    • Proceed immediately to stabilize the woman:
      • IV fluid volume replacement with 2 large-bore IV catheter
      • Oxygen by mask if available
      • If sepsis is suspected, obtain blood and cervical cultures if possible and start broad-spectrum IV antibiotics if indicated: Ampicillin, gentamicin and metronidazole
      • Obtain hemoglobin/hematocrit, blood type, and type and cross for blood transfusion if indicated
    • Determine underlying etiology of shock- e.g., ruptured ectopic pregnancy requires emergency surgery. > If etiology is from retained products of conception proceed with uterine evacuation ASAP
  6. Transfer to acute-care facility
    • If woman requires transfer to facility that can provide higher-acuity care, she may need stabilization and volume replacement with IV fluids before/during transport.
    • Notify referral facility and PSI that woman is being transported and give report on her diagnosis and condition.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-120-Counseling-Interacts with client in a respectful manner'
column5: 'Interacts with client in a respectful manner'
column6:
'

Interact with the client in a respectful manner. You must not create undue barriers or otherwise unnecessarily delay a client''s access to the service.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-130-Counseling-Explains misoprostol, MVA and expectant management
column5: potential side effects
column6: complications and eligibility for each method'
column11: complications and eligibility for each method'
column12:
'
  • Counsel on both medical and surgical abortion in detail. Explain how they are performed, the benefits of each, indications and contraindications for each method.
  • Consider that in certain cases expectant management is also possible.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-140-Counseling-Provider asks the woman to choose the method she prefers'
column5: 'Provider asks the woman to choose the method she prefers'
column6:
'

Allow the woman to choose among available methods that are appropriate, based on the duration of pregnancy and her medical condition. If she is not yet able to make a decision:

  • Ask if she has any questions
  • Review the benefits and limitations.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-150-Counseling-Explains the rapid return to fertility and the need to start contraception, and what methods are available'
column5: 'Explains the rapid return to fertility and the need to start contraception, and what methods are available'
column6:
'

Offer contraceptive counseling

  • Ensure the woman understands that ovulation returns 10-12 days after abortion, which could quickly lead to another pregnancy if she resumes sexual intercourse without using a modern contraceptive method.
  • If a woman desires contraception, provide it or refer for appropriate contraceptive services.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-160-Counseling-Provides the woman with information about risk factors for STIs and HIV'
column5: 'Provides the woman with information about risk factors for STIs and HIV'
column6:
'

Discuss how to prevent infection, and provide condoms if she wants them. If the woman has not been tested recently and would like to be, explain what that will involve and arrange for testing. If it is not available at your site, provide a referral.
Note: an HIV test is not a prerequisite for post abortion care.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-170-Counseling-Encourages the woman to ask any questions'
column5: 'Encourages the woman to ask any questions'
column6:
'

Give the woman a chance to ask questions and seek clarifications.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-180-Counseling-Check to make sure that client understands key messages conveyed'
column5: 'Check to make sure that client understands key messages conveyed'
column6:
'

Check to ensure the client understands key messages. You can ask her to tell you in her own words what she has understood.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-190-Counseling-Provides the woman with emergency contact information for the clinic or referral information for emergency care'
column5: 'Provides the woman with emergency contact information for the clinic or referral information for emergency care'
column6:
'

If is important for the woman to have emergency contact information incase she develops complications such as excessive bleeding.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-200-Counseling-Provider obtains and documents informed consent'
column5: 'Provider obtains and documents informed consent'
column6:
'
  • Informed consent assures that the woman''s decision is voluntary and informed.
  • Give accurate information regarding the risks, benefits, and possible complications of the method chosen.
  • There must be documentation that the woman understands the procedure and its alternatives
column7: the potential risks, benefits and complications
column8: that her decision is not coerced
column9: and that she is firm in her decision to have an abortion.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-210-Med Eval-Asks about her current pregnancy history, RH, surgical and medical history'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-210-Med Eval-Asks about her curr'
column5: 'Asks about her current pregnancy history, RH, surgical and medical history'
column6:
'

Obtain the following in medical history:

  1. Current medicines used
  2. Any known allergies
  3. Acute or chronic illnesses or conditions
  4. Brief obstetric and contraceptive history
  5. History of current pregnancy
    • Last Menstrual Period (LMP)
    • Gestational Age (GA)
    • Pregnancy symptoms
    • When bleeding began, bleeding patterns and amount of bleeding
    • Any agents used for induction of abortion? (i.e. misoprostol, tea, herbs, other tablets or substances, mechanical dilation, etc.)
    • Obtain history of tetanus vaccinations and assess risk for tetanus (i.e. sticks or other foreign objects inserted into uterus) and administer tetanus vaccine as per national protocols
    • Pelvic pain/ cramping -pattern and severity
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-220-Med Eval-Asks woman to empty her bladder before the examination'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-220-Med Eval-Asks woman to empty'
column5: 'Asks woman to empty her bladder before the examination'
column6:
'

This will avoid discomfort for the woman during abdominal, pelvic and speculum examinations.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-230-Med Eval-Provider washes hands and puts on gloves'
column5: 'Provider washes hands and puts on gloves'
column6:
'

Wash hands before and after examining a patient to avoid transfer of infections.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-240-Med Eval-General health assessment'
column5: 'General health assessment'
column6:
'

Proceed with general examination and note the following:

  • General appearance.
  • Vital signs.
  • Signs of weakness, lethargy, anaemia or malnourishment.
  • Signs or marks of physical violence.
  • General physical examination (as indicated).
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-250-Med Eval-Performs an abdominal examination'
column5: 'Performs an abdominal examination'
column6:
'

When performing an abdominal examination:

  • Palpate abdomen and check for suprapubic or pelvic tenderness and adnexal abnormalities.
  • Check if uterus is palpable abdominally to approximate gestational age.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-260-Med Eval-Uses a towel or sheet to ensure the client''s privacy is protected'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-260-Med Eval-Uses a towel or she'
column5: 'Uses a towel or sheet to ensure the client''s privacy is protected'
column6:
'

Ensure you always respect a client''s privacy and dignity.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-270-Med Eval-Provider discusses each step of exam with client as he/she proceeds'
column5: 'Provider discusses each step of exam with client as he/she proceeds'
column6:
'

Ensure the client is informed about the examination so as to allay anxiety and make her more co-operative during the examination.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-280-Med Eval-Appropriately performs a speculum examination'
column5: 'Appropriately performs a speculum examination'
column6:
'
  • Position her in lithotomy position.
  • Put on new exam (disposable) or HLD or sterile (reusable) gloves on both hands.
  • Clean the perineum and external genitalia
  • Inspect the external genitalia for ulcers or any abnormalities or signs of disease or infection.
  • Gently insert a warm appropriate size speculum and:
    • Check amount and source of any vaginal bleeding
column7: • Note any pus, discharge, lesions of the cervical os
column8: • Gently remove any visible products of conception from the os using a ring forceps
column9: • Identify traumatic injuries and remove any foreign bodies if present
column10:
• Take samples for culture if you suspect infection.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-290-Med Eval-Performs a bimanual exam'
column5: 'Performs a bimanual exam'
column6:
'

Next, perform Bimanual examination:

  • Assess the size, consistency and position of the uterus and adnexa
column7: • Note any uterine or adnexal masses or tenderness
column8: • Compare the size of the uterus with the history of amenorrhoea
column9: • Note whether the cervical os is open or closed
column10:
• If uncertain about the uterine size, ask another provider to assess or send the patient for an ultrasound scan.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-300-Med Eval-Rules out ectopic pregnancy'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-300-Med Eval-Rules out ectopic p'
column5: 'Rules out ectopic pregnancy'
column6:
'

Risk factors for Ectopic Pregnancy include:

  • History of Prior Ectopic Pregnancy
  • History of tubal surgery (i.e. tubal ligation)
  • IUD in place
  • Adnexal mass or pain on physical examination.

However, an ectopic pregnancy can occur in a woman without risk factors. Suspect ectopic pregnancy if:
Positive risk factors + Concerning physical exam
Signs and symptoms concerning for an ectopic pregnancy include: adnexal mass or adnexal pain on exam, hemodynamic instability, or peritoneal signs. If any of these signs are present, the woman should be treated as soon as possible or transferred immediately to a facility that can manage ectopic pregnancy.

NOTE: Findings on physical exam consistent with an ectopic pregnancy may be similar to findings present in the setting of a septic or unsafe abortion, in particular if the woman underwent a surgical procedure by an unskilled provider.

Refer suspected ectopic pregnancy for ultrasound then to a qualified provider for surgical management.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-310-Med Eval-Makes appropriate decision whether to proceed with the client''s chosen method and informs her appropriately'
column5: 'Makes appropriate decision whether to proceed with the client''s chosen method and informs her appropriately'
column6:
'

The final decision on the management plan depends of physical examination findings. It is important to discuss with the patient your examination findings and the next course of actions depending of the findings. If there are contraindications to offering either medical or surgical management, refer the woman appropriately.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-320-mPAC-Is the client receiving Misoprostol for Post Abortion Care? (mPAC)'
column5: 'Is the client receiving Misoprostol for Post Abortion Care? (mPAC)'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-330-mPAC-Confirms eligibility for misoprostol for post abortion care (mPAC)'
column5: 'Confirms eligibility for misoprostol for post abortion care (mPAC)'
column6:
'

Eligibility for misoprostol for treatment of incomplete abortion include:

  • Open cervical os
  • Vaginal bleeding or history of vaginal bleeding during this pregnancy
  • Uterine size of less than or equal to 12 weeks
  • Woman medically stable

Notes:

  • Women who are breastfeeding are eligible for misoprostol.
  • Women who have a history of a prior cesarean section are eligible for misoprostol in the first and second trimester.

Contraindications to misoprostol treatment of incomplete abortion include:

  • Known allergy to misoprostol or to other prostaglandins (very rare)
  • Confirmed or suspected ectopic pregnancy
  • Signs of sepsis
  • Hemodynamic instability or shock
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-340-mPAC-Explains to the woman what to expect'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-340-mPAC-Explains to the woman w'
column5: 'Explains to the woman what to expect'
column6:
'

Explain the following:

  • Effectiveness of treatment.
  • Range of normal experience.
  • Potential side effects and complications.
  • Warning signs to seek help and access to emergency care if needed.
  • Provide information where to get help - including emergency phone number.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-350-mPAC-Provides misoprostol and observes the woman in the clinic for several hours. If the woman is stable and prefers home treatment, allows her to take medicine and go home but counsels on when to return'
column5: 'Provides misoprostol and observes the woman in the clinic for several hours. If the woman is stable and prefers home treatment, allows her to take medicine and go home but counsels on when to return'
column6:
'

Depending on the facility space, the woman''s condition and her preference, she can take the medicines at the clinic and then return home, she can take the misoprostol once she is at home, or she can remain in the clinic for several hours for observation if facilities permit and this is the woman''s preference.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-360-mPAC-Provider gives the recommended regimen/dose'
column5: 'Provider gives the recommended regimen/dose'
column6:
'

Give either:

  • Oral misoprostol: 600mcg OR
  • Sublingual misoprostol: 400 mcg

For incomplete abortion in the first trimester, these doses are equally effective. Thus, the choice in regimens may depend on cultural/social attitudes concerning route of administration or cost.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-370-mPAC-Explains instructions for administration/ administers the drugs'
column5: 'Explains instructions for administration/ administers the drugs'
column6:
'

Describe how the pills should be taken

  • For sublingual, instruct women to place both misoprostol pills under the tongue and allow it to dissolve. Do not swallow. If fragments remain after 30 minutes, it is okay to swallow at that point.
  • For oral, instruct the woman to swallow all 3 pills at the same time.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-380-mPAC-Provides information on expected bleeding pattern and accompanying symptoms'
column5: 'Provides information on expected bleeding pattern and accompanying symptoms'
column6:
'

Explain the expected symptoms after taking misoprostol. They include:

  • Cramping and bleeding may begin as soon as 30 minutes after taking misoprostol.
  • Heavy bleeding may last for a few hours, but should not exceed soaking 2 pads per hour for 2 consecutive hours (see warning signs below).
