  • This initial heavy bleeding is often associated with passage of tissue and/or clots.
  • Total bleeding time is typically 5-8 days, but the majority of this is light to moderate.
  • Woman may experience chills, nausea, diarrhea, fever associated with the medication but these symptoms usual resolve on their own with 24 hours and do not require further treatment or care.

NOTE: Women can be counseled that should she experience the above symptoms, the pregnancy has likely passed and provided she has no other questions or concerns may not require a follow-up visit.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-390-mPAC-Counsels on warning signs'
column5: 'Counsels on warning signs'
column6:
'

Warning signs for which the woman should seek immediate medical care:

  • Heavy bleeding.
    • Soaking 2 full-thickness sanitary pads per hour for more than 2 consecutive hours.
    • Heavy bleeding that occurs after bleeding had slowed down or stopped.
    • Feeling light-headed, dizzy or weak as bleeding continues.
  • Fever that lasts more than a day or starts a day after the misoprostol is taken.
  • Severe pain, even on the day of misoprostol, that does not get better with medication, rest or a heating pad.
  • Severe nausea, vomiting or diarrhea or nausea, vomiting or diarrhea lasting more than 24 hours.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-400-mPAC-Provides additional medicines: analgesics, antiemetics'
column5: 'Provides additional medicines: analgesics, antiemetics'
column6:
'
  • For pain: NSAIDs such as ibuprofen 400-600 mg orally every 6 hours as needed.
column7:
>Note: Paracetamol is no longer recommended for pain control for PAC as studies have shown it to be less effective than NSAIDs (WHO, 2012).

  • Other medicines (e.g., anti-emetics) can be advised or prescribed as needed.
';'cpcuRMfOBGS';400;0.05;0.05;120;53;;162 744;'NG HNQIS PAC-410';'NG HNQIS PAC-410-mPAC-Assists the woman in identifying an appropriate support person';'NG HNQIS PAC-410-mPAC-Assists the woman in id';'Assists the woman in identifying an appropriate support person';'

A partner or support person present during home administration is encouraged.

';'MoA94s2bbFN';410;0.03;0.03;120;53;;162 745;'NG HNQIS PAC-420';'NG HNQIS PAC-420-mPAC-Advises follow-up (if needed) and gives a follow up date';'NG HNQIS PAC-420-mPAC-Advises follow-up (if n';'Advises follow-up (if needed) and gives a follow up date';'
  • Follow-up visit is not mandatory and women can be counseled that if they experienced the expected symptoms following misoprostol administration and they have no other questions or concerns they do not need to return to the clinic.
  • If you choose to schedule a routine follow-up visit, it is advisable to do so one to two weeks following misoprostol administration. At least 95% of women will be successful by 7 days post misoprostol administration.
';'p5Vau6teXdv';420;0.03;0.03;120;53;;162 746;'NG HNQIS PAC-430';'NG HNQIS PAC-430-mPAC-Records in the client file and Daily Activity Register';'NG HNQIS PAC-430-mPAC-Records in the client f';'Records in the client file and Daily Activity Register';'

Documentation is important after every procedure.

';'umc7T9XoUT4';430;0.03;0.03;120;53;;162 747;'NG HNQIS PAC-440';'NG HNQIS PAC-440-MVA-Is the client having an MVA procedure for Post abortion care?';'NG HNQIS PAC-440-MVA-Is the client having an';'Is the client having an MVA procedure for Post abortion care?';;'vLyCMxFPyMT';440;0.00;0.00;121;53;;163 748;'NG HNQIS PAC-450';'NG HNQIS PAC-450-MVA-PRE-PROCEDURE';'NG HNQIS PAC-450-MVA-PRE-PROCEDURE';'PRE-PROCEDURE';;'DhPt6VZ5ERm';450;0.00;0.00;121;49;;163 749;'NG HNQIS PAC-460';'NG HNQIS PAC-460-MVA-Confirms eligibility for MVA';'NG HNQIS PAC-460-MVA-Confirms eligibility for';'Confirms eligibility for MVA';'

There are very few absolute contraindications to MVA procedures; however, the following cases may require a higher level facility for care or the procedure should be performed by a more experienced provider.

  • Uterine anomaly
  • Fibroids > 16 weeks or obstructing cervical canal
  • Severe anemia (Hb < 7)
  • Uncontrolled seizure disorder
  • Known or suspected molar pregnancy > 12 weeks
  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Significant cardiopulmonary disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Severe infection requiring IV antibiotics
';'S0x0CBLgFw4';460;0.10;0.10;121;53;;163 750;'NG HNQIS PAC-470';'NG HNQIS PAC-470-MVA-Determines a pain management plan and provides it';'NG HNQIS PAC-470-MVA-Determines a pain manage';'Determines a pain management plan and provides it';'

Decide on a pain management plan
Most women undergoing first-trimester vacuum aspiration will experience some pain. Generally a combination of pharmacologic pain medications, including local anesthesia (in the form of a paracervical block) and non-pharmacologic measures provide pain relief for most women.

  • Non-pharmacologic pain management: medications should be supplemented with supportive techniques to decrease pain and anxiety.
  • Pharmacologic pain management:
    • Include NSAIDS, analgesics, narcotics and anxiolytics. At a minimum, premedication with an NSAID should be given. Recommendation: Give Ibuprofen 400-800mg orally one hour prior to MVA procedure.
    • Paracetamol is no longer recommended as a first line pain medication, but may be used as an antipyretic if needed.
    • Paracervical block: a paracervical block with up to 20mL of lidocaine (one percent) given several minutes before dilating the cervix has been shown to decrease pain with dilation and aspiration.
    • Intravenous sedation is also effective. However, providing intravenous sedation increases the expense, complexity and potential risks of the procedure.
';'QxNPaBXG5o2';470;0.05;0.05;121;53;;163 751;'NG HNQIS PAC-480';'NG HNQIS PAC-480-MVA-Provides necessary antibiotics';'NG HNQIS PAC-480-MVA-Provides necessary antib';'Provides necessary antibiotics';'
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended for all women prior to vacuum aspiration. However, where antibiotics are unavailable uterine aspiration may still be offered.
  • Therapeutic antibiotics should be administered to all women who are suspected of or who have been diagnosed with an infection.
    • Women at high risk should be screened and treated for sexually transmitted infections in addition to receiving prophylactic antibiotics.
    • Women who have signs and symptoms of active infection should still receive the MVA service without delay but should simultaneously be started on appropriate therapeutic antibiotics.
';'RQg1XqNxkjj';480;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 752;'NG HNQIS PAC-490';'NG HNQIS PAC-490-MVA-Explains the procedure and encourages the client to ask questions';'NG HNQIS PAC-490-MVA-Explains the procedure a';'Explains the procedure and encourages the client to ask questions';'

Explain to the patient the procedure. She has a right to receive information. This will also allay anxiety in her.

';'mFiO8iBc1Iq';490;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 753;'NG HNQIS PAC-500';'NG HNQIS PAC-500-MVA-Explains that some procedure steps may be uncomfortable but reassures the client';'NG HNQIS PAC-500-MVA-Explains that some proce';'Explains that some procedure steps may be uncomfortable but reassures the client';'

This will help the woman tolerate the pain and discomfort better.

';'tSLxTXPLCUo';500;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 754;'NG HNQIS PAC-510';'NG HNQIS PAC-510-MVA-Confirms all equipment is available';'NG HNQIS PAC-510-MVA-Confirms all equipment i';'Confirms all equipment is available';'

Ensure you have all the equipment before starting. MVA is a sterile procedure hence once you start, you should not touch anything outside the sterile field.

';'iEiVsgSleze';510;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 755;'NG HNQIS PAC-520';'NG HNQIS PAC-520-MVA-Ensures appropriate size of cannulae and adapters are available';'NG HNQIS PAC-520-MVA-Ensures appropriate size';'Ensures appropriate size of cannulae and adapters are available';'

Do not proceed with an MVA if you do not have appropriate sizes of cannulae and adapters; you may not be able to achieve a vacuum for the process to be effective.

';'I7mcQNMITen';520;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 756;'NG HNQIS PAC-530';'NG HNQIS PAC-530-MVA-Checks the MVA syringe and charges it (to establish vacuum)';'NG HNQIS PAC-530-MVA-Checks the MVA syringe a';'Checks the MVA syringe and charges it (to establish vacuum)';'
  • Check that you have a vacuum. If vacuum is not retained, check the O-ring and lubricate if necessary.
  • If vacuum is still not retained, discard and use another aspirator. Discard aspirators with visible cracks or defects.
';'gpW1k3XVRyS';530;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 757;'NG HNQIS PAC-540';'NG HNQIS PAC-540-MVA-Checks that patient has recently emptied her bladder';'NG HNQIS PAC-540-MVA-Checks that patient has';'Checks that patient has recently emptied her bladder';'

A full bladder will cause discomfort for the woman during the procedure.

';'c6WHxdY16zE';540;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 758;'NG HNQIS PAC-550';'NG HNQIS PAC-550-MVA-Checks that patient has thoroughly washed and rinsed her perineal area';'NG HNQIS PAC-550-MVA-Checks that patient has';'Checks that patient has thoroughly washed and rinsed her perineal area';'
  • Fecal matter soiling in the perennial area should be cleaned to avoid contamination since it is a sterile procedure.
';'Z17mUidbnVH';550;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 759;'NG HNQIS PAC-560';'NG HNQIS PAC-560-MVA-Washes hands and dries them';'NG HNQIS PAC-560-MVA-Washes hands and dries t';'Washes hands and dries them';'
  • Wash hands routinely to avoid spreading infections.
  • Dry hands to make gloving easy.
';'sydumhUjQNg';560;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 760;'NG HNQIS PAC-570';'NG HNQIS PAC-570-MVA-Puts on new sterile gloves on both hands';'NG HNQIS PAC-570-MVA-Puts on new sterile glov';'Puts on new sterile gloves on both hands';'

MVA is a sterile procedure, observe infection prevention protocol.

';'Ov70IU5dxUT';570;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 761;'NG HNQIS PAC-580';'NG HNQIS PAC-580-MVA-Arranges sterile instruments on sterile tray';'NG HNQIS PAC-580-MVA-Arranges sterile instrum';'Arranges sterile instruments on sterile tray';'

Arrange the necessary equipment on a sterile before starting. These include:

  • MVA instruments: aspirator, cannulae of various sizes, and silicone or other suitable lubricant
  • Tenaculum
  • Speculum
  • Sponge forceps or uterine-packing forceps
  • Mechanical dilators (if not using cannulae for this purpose)
  • Betadine or other nonalcoholic antiseptic
  • Paracervical block supplies: anesthetic (0.5% or 1.0% Lidocaine) without epinephrine and a 5, 10 or 20ml syringe with 21- or 22-gauge (or finer) regular or spinal needle
  • Tissue inspection supplies: strainer, clear bowl, light source, forceps and water
';'fgyLHffugwg';580;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 762;'NG HNQIS PAC-590';'NG HNQIS PAC-590-MVA-MVA PROCEDURE';'NG HNQIS PAC-590-MVA-MVA PROCEDURE';'MVA PROCEDURE';;'QFI4daqygDc';590;0.00;0.00;121;49;;163 763;'NG HNQIS PAC-600';'NG HNQIS PAC-600-MVA-Performs bimanual pelvic examination to confirm uterine size, position and degree of cervical dilation (only if patient returns on different day of primary examination)';'NG HNQIS PAC-600-MVA-Performs bimanual pelvic';'Performs bimanual pelvic examination to confirm uterine size, position and degree of cervical dilation (only if patient returns on different day of primary examination)';'
  • Bimanual pelvic examination needs to be performed again if the MVA is not done immediately with the medical evaluation.
  • Note the degree of cervical dilation to be able to pick the appropriate size of cannula.
';'gCM0WAMpqdB';600;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 764;'NG HNQIS PAC-610';'NG HNQIS PAC-610-MVA-Inserts the speculum and removes blood or tissue from vagina using sponge holding forceps and sterile gauze';'NG HNQIS PAC-610-MVA-Inserts the speculum and';'Inserts the speculum and removes blood or tissue from vagina using sponge holding forceps and sterile gauze';'

This will enable you visualize the cervix and os clearly.

';'T2tFWpn1DZm';610;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 765;'NG HNQIS PAC-620';'NG HNQIS PAC-620-MVA-Removes any products of conception protruding from the cervical os and checks the cervix for tears';'NG HNQIS PAC-620-MVA-Removes any products of';'Removes any products of conception protruding from the cervical os and checks the cervix for tears';'
  • POCs protruding from the os can be removed with forceps gently. These may be large and will obstruct insertion of the cannula.
  • Check for tears which may have been as a result of attempted abortion by an unskilled provider.
';'xKD9NFHV7Ne';620;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 766;'NG HNQIS PAC-630';'NG HNQIS PAC-630-MVA-Applies appropriate antiseptic to cervix and vagina three times.';'NG HNQIS PAC-630-MVA-Applies appropriate anti';'Applies appropriate antiseptic to cervix and vagina three times.';'

MVA is a sterile procedure and swabbing the cervix three times minimizes the risk of introducing infection into the uterus.

  • Cleanse from the center of the cervical os moving outward on the cervix and into the surrounding vaginal canal.
  • If povidone iodine is used, allow 1 to 2 minutes before proceeding.
  • Do not use alcohol as it is painful for the woman; dries and damages the mucous membranes, which may support the infectious process.
';'XuEVmI9t1RS';630;0.03;0.03;121;53;;163 767;'NG HNQIS PAC-640';'NG HNQIS PAC-640-MVA-Puts single tooth tenaculum or vulsellum forceps on lower lip of cervix (5 or 7 o’clock).';'NG HNQIS PAC-640-MVA-Puts single tooth tenacu';'Puts single tooth tenaculum or vulsellum forceps on lower lip of cervix (5 or 7 o’clock).';'

The tenaculum is used to align the uterus with the cervical opening and to stabilize the cervix for easier insertion of the cannula.

';'Mb0E6tSgl13';640;0.02;0.02;121;53;;163 768;'NG HNQIS PAC-650';'NG HNQIS PAC-650-MVA-Correctly administers paracervical block (if necessary) as per protocol';'NG HNQIS PAC-650-MVA-Correctly administers pa';'Correctly administers paracervical block (if necessary) as per protocol';'

Administer paracervical block as follows:

  • Load a 20mL syringe with 12mL of lidocaine (one percent) (If sodium bicarbonate solution is available a buffered solution may be prepared: Load 20mL syringe with 18mL of 1% lidocaine and load 2mL sodium bicarbonate (8.4 percent))
  • Attach syringe to a 20-gauge spinal needle (or use a 20-gauge needle with a needle extender").
  • Infiltrate 2mL into the cervix superficially at the tenaculum site (12 o''clock or 6 o''clock).
  • Grasp the cervix at the site of the previously injected local with the single-tooth or atraumatic vulsellum tenaculum.
  • Inject the remaining lidocaine in equal amounts at the cervicovaginal junction at the locations of four and eight o''clock just above the uterosacral ligament. (Some clinicians also prefer to inject at 2, 4, 8 and 10 o''clock).
  • The injection should be continuous from superficial to a depth of one to three centimeters.
  • Pull back on the plunger before injecting anesthesia to prevent intravascular injection.
  • Inspect the injection sites for bleeding (may need to hold pressure if bleeding).
  • Begin procedure at least three minutes after the paracervical block is complete.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-660-MVA-Gently applies traction on the cervix to straighten the cervical canal and uterine cavity'
column5: 'Gently applies traction on the cervix to straighten the cervical canal and uterine cavity'
column6:
'

Apply gentle traction to avoid tearing the cervix.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-670-MVA-Dilates the cervix (if needed)/proceeds if not needed'
column5: 'Dilates the cervix (if needed)/proceeds if not needed'
column6:
'
  • Cervical dilatation is necessary when the cervical canal will not allow passage of a cannula appropriate to the uterine size.
  • When required, dilatation should be done gently with progressively larger cannulae or tapered mechanical dilators, taking care not to traumatize the cervix.
  • Misoprostol can also be used to ripen the cervix.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-680-MVA-While holding the cervix steady, pushes the selected cannula gently and slowly into the uterine cavity until it just touches the fundus (not >10 cm). Then withdraws the cannula slightly away from the fundus'
column5: 'While holding the cervix steady, pushes the selected cannula gently and slowly into the uterine cavity until it just touches the fundus (not >10 cm). Then withdraws the cannula slightly away from the fundus'
column6:
'
  • Do not insert the cannula forcefully, as forceful movements may cause uterine perforation or damage to the cervix, pelvic organs or blood vessels. Rotate the cannula with gentle pressure to help ease insertion.
  • Remain alert to signals that may indicate perforation throughout the procedure and stop suction immediately if they appear.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-690-MVA-Performs suction as per protocol using the no-touch technique.'
column5: 'Performs suction as per protocol using the no-touch technique.'
column6:
'

Perform suction as follows:

  • Attach cannula to aspirator, holding the tenaculum and end of the cannula in one hand and the aspirator in the other. Take care not to push the cannula further into the uterus.
  • Release vacuum by pressing the buttons in
column7:
suction will begin immediately.
  • Evacuate by slowly and gently rotating cannula and aspirator 180 degrees in each direction while using an in-and-out motion. Take care not to withdraw the aperture of the cannula beyond the cervical os, as this will cause a loss of vacuum.
  • If the syringe becomes half full before the procedure is complete, detach the cannula from the syringe. Remove only the syringe, leaving the cannula in place. Never push aspirated contents through the cannula into the uterus.
  • Push the plunger to empty POC into the strainer.
  • Recharge syringe, attach to cannula and release buttons.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-700-MVA-Checks for signs of completion'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-700-MVA-Checks for signs of comp'
column5: 'Checks for signs of completion'
column6:
'

The following signs indicate completion:

  • Red or pink foam without tissue passes through the cannula
column7: • Gritty sensation as the cannula passes over the surface of the evacuated uterus
column9:
• The woman feels increased cramping when the uterus is empty, indicating contraction.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-710-MVA-Removes cannula from the MVA syringe and pushes the plunger to empty contents into the strainer'
column5: 'Removes cannula from the MVA syringe and pushes the plunger to empty contents into the strainer'
column6:
'
  • When the procedure is finished, depress the buttons and disconnect the cannula from the aspirator.
  • Alternatively, withdraw the cannula and aspirator together. Without depressing the buttons, empty contents into strainer.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-720-MVA-Quickly inspects the tissue removed from the uterus to be sure the uterus is completely evacuated'
column5: 'Quickly inspects the tissue removed from the uterus to be sure the uterus is completely evacuated'
column6:
'
  • Inspect aspirated tissue for quantity and presence or absence of products of conception (POC).
  • You can rinse the tissues with water or saline to enable better visualization.
  • This is extremely important since it indicates whether the evacuation was complete or whether there is the possibility of an ectopic or molar pregnancy.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-730-MVA-If no products of conception are seen, reassess situation to be sure it is not an ectopic pregnancy'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-730-MVA-If no products of concep'
column5: 'If no products of conception are seen, reassess situation to be sure it is not an ectopic pregnancy'
column6:
'

If no products of conception (POCs) are seen, the possibility of ectopic pregnancy, incomplete abortion or a complete spontaneous abortion should be considered.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-740-MVA-Determines the procedure is complete'
column5: 'Determines the procedure is complete'
column6:
'

Determine completion:

  • Wipe away excess blood from the os and assess the quantity still coming from the uterus or elsewhere. Ensure that bleeding is minimal.
  • Remove the speculum.
  • Perform bimanual examination to check size and firmness of the uterus.
  • If suspected remained products of conception, repeat the MVA procedure.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-750-MVA-Cleans the woman and provides her with a pad.'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-750-MVA-Cleans the woman and pro'
column5: 'Cleans the woman and provides her with a pad.'
column6:
'

After completing the evacuation, clean the woman
column7: provide her with a sanitary pad
column8: and position her in a recovery position
column9:
or help her to a recovery bed.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-760-MVA-POST-MVA TASKS'
column5: 'POST-MVA TASKS'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-770-MVA-Post MVA Infection Prevention procedures correctly performed'
column5: 'Post MVA Infection Prevention procedures correctly performed'
column6:
'
  • Before removing gloves, dispose of waste materials in a leak-proof container or plastic bag.
  • Place speculum and metal instruments in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
  • If reusing needle or syringe, fill syringe (with needle attached) with 0.5% chlorine solution and submerge in solution for 10 minutes for decontamination. If disposing of needle and syringe, flush needle and syringe with 0.5% chlorine solution three times, then place in puncture proof container.
  • Attach used cannula to MVA syringe and flush both with 0.5% chlorine solution.
  • Detach cannulae from syringe and soak them in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
  • Empty POC into utility sink, flushable toilet, latrine or container with tightfitting lid.
  • Appropriately removes and disposes gloves.
  • Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water and dry with clean, dry cloth or air dry.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-780-MVA-Allows the patient to rest comfortably for at least 30 minutes where her recovery can be monitored'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-780-MVA-Allows the patient to re'
column5: 'Allows the patient to rest comfortably for at least 30 minutes where her recovery can be monitored'
column6:
'

Monitor the woman''s recovery
Have the woman rest in a comfortable position. Assess and respond sensitively to her emotional state. Monitor her until she has:

  • pulse and blood pressure that is normal for her
column7: • the ability to walk and drink fluids

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-790-MVA-Checks for bleeding at least once and ensure that cramping has decreased before discharge'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-790-MVA-Checks for bleeding at l'
column5: 'Checks for bleeding at least once and ensure that cramping has decreased before discharge'
column6:
'
  • Check the sanitary pad for signs of heavy bleeding.
  • Ask her whether the cramping has reduced.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-800-MVA-Instructs patient regarding post abortion care'
column5: 'Instructs patient regarding post abortion care'
column6:
'

Give instructions on:

  • instructions for taking medications
  • information about routine hygiene
  • information about resumption of sexual activity and contraception
  • signs and symptoms requiring emergency attention
  • where to seek emergency care, if needed
  • list of counseling and other available services
  • date, time and location of follow-up visit
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-810-MVA-Counsels on warning signs and signs of a normal recovery'
column5: 'Counsels on warning signs and signs of a normal recovery'
column6:
'

Warning signs include:

  • fever, chills, nausea or vomiting for more than 24 hours
  • cramping for more than a few days
  • tenderness, pain or distention of the abdomen
  • heavy bleeding (more than normal menstrual bleeding)
  • foul-smelling vaginal discharge
  • delay in resumption of menstrual period by more than eight weeks
  • fainting or dizziness.

Signs of a normal recovery include:

  • Some uterine cramping can be expected over the next few days, similar to that of a normal menstrual period.
  • Discomfort may be eased by mild analgesics, warm compress or bath.
  • Spotting and bleeding should not exceed normal menses.
  • A normal period should begin within four to eight weeks.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-820-MVA-Tells her when to return if follow-up is needed and that she can return anytime or call if she has concerns.'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-820-MVA-Tells her when to return'
column5: 'Tells her when to return if follow-up is needed and that she can return anytime or call if she has concerns.'
column6:
'
  • Give the patient a follow up date.
  • Tell her that she can return to the facility anytime she has concerns.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-830-MVA-Discusses reproductive goals and, as appropriate, provides/counsels on family planning.'
column5: 'Discusses reproductive goals and, as appropriate, provides/counsels on family planning.'
column6:
'

Review her reproductive health goals. Women should be given detailed information regarding the following

  • Post abortion contraception
    • Women can become pregnant as soon as 10 days after the procedure.
    • Contraception can help prevent pregnancy.
    • Contraceptive counseling and the woman''s method of choice should ideally be provided before she leaves the clinic.
  • HIV
    • Unprotected sex may have exposed her to HIV infection.
    • The earlier a woman knows her HIV status the better
column7:
if a woman is HIV-positive, she could access care and support services that can prolong and increase the quality of her life.
  • Safer sexual practices, such as condom use, may reduce the risk of receiving or transmitting HIV as well as other sexually transmitted infections.
  • Offer voluntary HIV counseling and testing, as well as referrals to local HIV/AIDS support groups.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS PAC-840-MVA-Records in the client file and Daily Activity Register'
column4: 'NG HNQIS PAC-840-MVA-Records in the client fi'
column5: 'Records in the client file and Daily Activity Register'
column6:
'

Documentation is important after every procedure.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-100-Inq-Is this a female client?'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-100-Inq-Is this a female client?'
column5: 'Is this a female client?'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-110-Inq-Ensures privacy (Visual and auditory)'
column5: 'Ensures privacy (Visual and auditory)'
column6:
'
  • Ensure the room provides privacy. Patients are often embarrassed and may withhold important information if they think their condition will become known to others.
  • Reassure the patient that confidentiality will be maintained and explain the reason for asking certain questions.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-120-Inq-Provider is polite and non-judgmental'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-120-Inq-Provider is polite and n'
column5: 'Provider is polite and non-judgmental'
column6:
'
  • Create rapport with the patient.
  • Do not create undue barriers to a client seeking STI services.
  • Effective interviewing and counseling skills characterized by respect, compassion, and a nonjudgmental attitude toward all patients are essential to obtaining a thorough sexual history and delivering effective prevention messages.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-130-Inq-Asks about onset and history of current problem relating to the genital area and associated symptoms'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-130-Inq-Asks about onset and his'
column5: 'Asks about onset and history of current problem relating to the genital area and associated symptoms'
column6:
'

Take detailed history

  • Find out the symptoms and their duration. The symptoms to look out for are: genital ulcer/sore, vaginal discharge, pain passing urine, lower abdominal pains.
  • Presumed source and time of infection.
  • Medication, self administered or prescribed.
  • Ask about associated symptoms: fever, intermenstrual bleeding, post-coital bleeding.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-140-Inq-Takes sexual history: type of partner (spouse or casual), date of last encounter, type of exposure (oral, vaginal, anal) regularity of condom use'
column5: 'Takes sexual history: type of partner (spouse or casual), date of last encounter, type of exposure (oral, vaginal, anal) regularity of condom use'
column6:
'

Sexual history

  • Important in determining which STI the patient could be having.
  • Provides the ground for counseling on behaviour change.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-150-Inq-Ask if sexual partner has symptoms'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-150-Inq-Ask if sexual partner ha'
column5: 'Ask if sexual partner has symptoms'
column6:
'

Ask if partner has any symptoms

  • This may help in confirmation of presence of an STI.
  • Introducing discussion on the partner provides an opportunity to counsel on partner tracing and treatment, and to prevent re-infection. However, remember the partner(s) may well be asymptomatic.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-160-Inq-Asks for history of STI in the past, including genital herpes'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-160-Inq-Asks for history of STI'
column5: 'Asks for history of STI in the past, including genital herpes'
column6:
'

Ask for history of previous STI infection

  • This may indicate repeated risky behaviour
column7:
repeated exposure from partner or persistence of symptoms from the previous episode.
  • Determine the treatment that was given for the previous STI, if there is history of previous STI.
  • Determine if the sexual partner(s) was treated during the last episode, as the client could be presenting with a re-infection from the same partner.
  • In such a client, emphasize risk reduction. Spend time helping the client to identify a risk reduction plan.
  • Emphasize contact tracing and treatment and have a follow up plan for the client.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-170-Inq-Provider asks about HIV status'
column5: 'Provider asks about HIV status'
column6:
'

Ask about the client''s HIV status

  • A client seeking STI services provides an opportunity for HIV counseling and testing.
  • A client coming for STI screening within 72 hours of sexual exposure and agrees to HIV testing will benefit from HIV post-exposure prophylaxis if the HIV test result turns negative.
  • Behaviors that put someone at risk of STI (not using condoms, multiple partners, anonymous partners) are the same risk factors for HIV infection to oneself and partner.
  • A sore or inflammation from an STD increases the risk of HIV infection.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-180-Inq-Obtains consent before proceeding with examination (verbal) without coercion'
column5: 'Obtains consent before proceeding with examination (verbal) without coercion'
column6:
'
  • Before undertaking any physical examination, seek client or guardian consent.
  • A client has a right to make choices concerning their body/health. As a provider, give all the information required concerning the illness,importance of examination and the procedure to be done to ensure the consent is informed.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-190-PE-Explains the examination procedure and its importance'
column5: 'Explains the examination procedure and its importance'
column6:
'

Explain the examination procedure

  • A client has a right to information regarding their health.
  • Explaining the procedure will allay anxiety and enhance client co-operation during examination especially because genital examinations are embarrassing to most people.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-200-PE-Provider gets a chaperone if the client is not of the same sex'
column5: 'Provider gets a chaperone if the client is not of the same sex'
column6:
'

Have a chaperone during the physical examination

  • This may be another health worker or the partner if they came for treatment together.
  • This will make the client more comfortable.
  • It also helps prevent potential medico-legal complaints regarding sexual/indecent assault against the provider/client.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-210-PE-Prepares equipment and area'
column5: 'Prepares equipment and area'
column6:
'

Prepare equipment and area prior to starting an examination. Have the following supplies/equipment:

  • Examination lamp
  • Examination couch
  • Bi-valved speculums (different sizes)
  • Antiseptic
  • Gloves
  • Lubricant
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-220-PE-Prepares the client adequately'
column5: 'Prepares the client adequately'
column6:
'

Prepare patient adequately

  • Ask the client to empty her bladder for the examination to be more comfortable.
  • Ask her to clean the perineal area if it is soiled.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-230-PE-Ensures privacy during examination'
column5: 'Ensures privacy during examination'
column6:
'

Ensure the door is closed during the examination and draw the curtains around the examination couch.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-240-PE-Washes hands before examination'
column5: 'Washes hands before examination'
column6:
'

Wash hands before and after an encounter with every patient to prevent spread of microorganisms

  • Wash hands with soap and clean running water.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-250-PE-Puts on new gloves'
column5: 'Puts on new gloves'
column6:
'
  • Gloves are important for infection prevention.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-260-PE-Positions the client for examination'
column5: 'Positions the client for examination'
column6:
'
  • Help the woman onto the examination couch.
  • Ask the woman to loosen her clothing. Use a sheet or clothing to cover her.
  • Have her lie on her back, with her heels close to her bottom and her knees up.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-270-PE-Performs a general examination'
column5: 'Performs a general examination'
column6:
'

All examinations should begin with a general assessment, including vital signs and inspection of the skin, to detect signs of systemic disease.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-280-PE-Performs abdominal examination by palpation'
column5: 'Performs abdominal examination by palpation'
column6:
'
  • All sexually active women presenting with lower abdominal pain should be carefully evaluated for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  • In addition, routine abdominal examination should be carried out on all women with a presumptive STI since some women with PID or endometritis will not complain of lower abdominal pain.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-290-PE-Palpates for inguinal lymph nodes'
column5: 'Palpates for inguinal lymph nodes'
column6:
'

Examine inguinal lymph nodes checking for enlargement, tenderness, consistency and whether they are ,matted or not

  • Inguinal and femoral buboes are localised enlargements of the lymph nodes in the groin area, which are painful and may be fluctuant. They are frequently associated with LGV and chancroid. In many cases of chancroid an associated genital ulcer is visible.
  • However, remember that Non-sexually transmitted local and systemic infections (e.g. infections of the lower limb or tuberculous lymphadenopathy) can also cause swelling of inguinal lymph nodes.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-300-PE-Examines external genitalia looking for ulcers and separates the labia while inspecting'
column5: 'Examines external genitalia looking for ulcers and separates the labia while inspecting'
column6:
'
  • Carry out the examination in good light.
  • Examine the external genitalia.
  • Using the gloved hand, gently look for lumps, swelling, sores, vesicles.
  • Separate the labia to look to examine the inner aspects of the vulva.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-310-PE-Performs vaginal examination as per protocol'
column5: 'Performs vaginal examination as per protocol'
column6:
'

Check the vaginal opening for any discharge, the colour, consistency and smell of the discharge.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-320-PE-Performs speculum examination'
column5: 'Performs speculum examination'
column6:
'
  • Clean the perineum and external genitalia using the five swab technique.
  • Gently insert a warm appropriate size speculum.
  • Be careful not to press on the urethra or clitoris because these areas are very sensitive.
  • Fix the blades to visualize the cervix.
  • Check for vaginal discharge.
  • Look for signs of cervical infection by checking for yellowish discharge or easy bleeding when the cervix is touched with a swab.
  • Note any abnormal growths or sores on the cervix.
  • Notice if the cervical os is open or closed, and whether there is any bleeding.
  • Take samples for culture (if required and resources are available).
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-330-PE-Performs bimanual palpation'
column5: 'Performs bimanual palpation'
column6:
'

Perform bimanual exam

  • Lubricate your gloved fingers.
  • Gently insert two fingers into the vagina. Place the other hand gently on the lower abdomen.
  • Gently move the cervix from side to side ("cervical rocking" test) and observe for tenderness (cervical motion tenderness) which is a sign of PID.
  • Check for cervical mobility.
  • Palpate the uterus by pressing down on the lower part of the abdomen and moving the fingers behind the cervix to push the uterus towards your abdominal hand. Feel for its size and shape.
    • If it feels soft and large, she is probably pregnant
    • If it feels lumpy and hard, she may have a fibroid or other growth
    • If it tender, she may have PID
    • If it is not freely mobile, she could have adhesions from an old infection.
  • Palpate the right and left adenexae gently by moving your fingers on the sides of the cervix. Gently press down with the abdominal hand. At the same time, press up with your vaginal fingers and feel for masses.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-340-PE-Examines perianal area'
column5: 'Examines perianal area'
column6:
'

Examine the anal area

  • Ask the patient to lie on her side with the top leg flexed up towards the chest.
  • Examine the anus for ulcers, warts, rashes, or discharge.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-350-Post Exam-Post -examination IP procedures correctly performed'
column5: 'Post -examination IP procedures correctly performed'
column6:
'

Observe infection prevention procedures

  • Immediately soak ALL the instruments used after procedure, or contaminated in any way, in a plastic bucket with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite (chlorine) solution for 10 minutes.
  • Dispose of waste material in leak proof container or plastic bag.
  • Decontaminate couch or other surfaces contaminated during the procedure by wiping with 5% chlorine solution.
  • After soaking for 10 minutes, remove instruments from solution.
  • Clean instruments immediately.
  • Remove gloves following the glove removal procedure.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-360-Post Exam-Washes hands after examination'
column5: 'Washes hands after examination'
column6:
'

Wash hands with soap and running water after examining a patient or performing a procedure to prevent spread of microorganisms.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-370-DxTx-Makes a correct diagnosis'
column5: 'Makes a correct diagnosis'
column6:
'

Make a diagnosis following the flow charts/algorithms.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-380-DxTx-Gives the correct treatment using the standard flow charts/algorithms'
column5: 'Gives the correct treatment using the standard flow charts/algorithms'
column6:
'

Identify treatment using the flow charts/algorithms

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-390-Counseling-Provider uses education material during counseling'
column5: 'Provider uses education material during counseling'
column6:
'

It is important to use education material to enhance understanding during counseling. The material should cover the critical areas which include:

  • Counseling
  • Compliance to recommended treatment
  • Condoms
  • Contact treatment
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-400-Counseling-Provides information about the current STI, including transmission and prevention'
column5: 'Provides information about the current STI, including transmission and prevention'
column6:
'
  • Inform the client what STI they have.
  • Discuss mechanisms of transmission.
  • Discuss potential health complications that can arise if the STI is not treated e.g. Pelvic infections
column10:
transmission of infection to the new born baby among others.
  • Discuss risky sexual behaviour that increases the risk of getting an STI.
  • Discuss ways of preventing infection with STIs including:
    • delaying sexual activity (for adolescents)
column12:
• using condoms correctly and consistently.
  • early treatment of STI to prevent infection to others.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-410-Counseling-Counsels on drug dosage, duration of treatment including side effects'
column5: 'Counsels on drug dosage, duration of treatment including side effects'
column6:
'

Counsel on proper dosage

  • Counsel on specific doses per day, total number of days of treatment, and potential side effects
column7: including severe side effects that require a return visit to hospital.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-420-Counseling-Provider explores barriers to treatment adherence'
column5: 'Provider explores barriers to treatment adherence'
column6:
'
  • Adherence to treatment and completion of the dose is essential to break the STI transmission cycle and to prevent complications.
  • Explore issues that might hinder treatment such as: fear of spouse/partner discovering they are on treatment for an STI.
  • Discuss with the client ways of tackling the barriers.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-430-Counseling-DOT for single dose drugs offered on site/first dose given on site'
column5: 'DOT for single dose drugs offered on site/first dose given on site'
column6:
'
  • WHO recommends that, where possible, single-dose therapy be used.
  • It is also preferred to initiate treatment as soon as possible.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-440-Counseling-Counsels on risk reduction'
column5: 'Counsels on risk reduction'
column6:
'

Counsel the client on risk reduction to prevent re-infection

  • Abstinence/reduction of number of sexual partners.
  • Correct and consistent condom use.
  • Delaying sexual activity for adolescents and young people.
  • Remaining faithful to one uninfected partner.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-450-Counseling-Counsels on HIV testing and offers the test/refers for the test if the client is willing.'
column5: 'Counsels on HIV testing and offers the test/refers for the test if the client is willing.'
column6:
'
  • Both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs increase the risk of sexual transmission of HIV.
  • A client at risk of STI is also at risk of HIV.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-460-Counseling-Counsels and demonstrates condom use and provides the client with condoms'
column5: 'Counsels and demonstrates condom use and provides the client with condoms'
column6:
'

Condom use

  • Correct and consistent condom use is the most reliable method available method of protecting oneself or their partner from any risk of STIs.
  • STIs can still occur despite condom use: genital ulcers or warts can be transmitted through contact with parts of the body not covered by the condom.
  • Condoms may fail if: handled or stored incorrectly e.g. in wallets or in a hot place
column7:
or if used with oil-based lubricants.
  • Condom breakage is usually due to incorrect use, not due to defects in the device.
  • When used correctly during every act of intercourse, condoms can greatly reduce the risks of both pregnancy and STI (dual protection), including HIV infection.
  • Demonstrate condom use, do not make an assumption that the patient knows how to use condoms.
  • Provide the client with condom supply/ advice client to buy if not available for free distribution.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-470-Counseling-Counsels on contact tracing, partner notification and treatment'
column5: 'Counsels on contact tracing, partner notification and treatment'
column6:
'

Ask the client to bring partner(s) for treatment/advice partner to come for treatment

  • The sexual partner(s) of STI patients are likely to be infected and should be offered treatment.
  • Further transmission of STIs and reinfection can be prevented by referral of sexual partners for diagnosis and treatment.
  • Partner notification and management offers an opportunity to identify and treat people who otherwise would not receive treatment.
  • In case the source of infection was from a casual sexual encounter and there has been no sexual contact with the regular partner/spouse, counsel on importance of preventing transmission to the partner.
  • These actions, however, should be carried out with sensitivity and consideration of social and cultural factors to avoid ethical and practical problems such as rejection and violence, against the woman.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-480-Counseling-Explains re-infection in case the partner is not treated'
column5: 'Explains re-infection in case the partner is not treated'
column6:
'

Emphasize that re-infection will occur if the sexual partner is not treated, regardless of whether the partner is symptomatic or not.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-490-Counseling-Explains where and when to seek follow up care, and gives a follow up visit date'
column5: 'Explains where and when to seek follow up care, and gives a follow up visit date'
column6:
'
  • For continuity of care, it is better for the client to return to the same facility if they have problems.
  • Give the client a number for the facility they can call to ask any question.
  • Give the client a follow up visit if required.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-500-Counseling-Allows the client to ask questions'
column5: 'Allows the client to ask questions'
column6:
'

Always give the client an opportunity to ask questions and to seek clarifications. If you do not give them a chance, they may feel embarrassed to ask and may end up leaving the clinic with a problem or without understanding your instructions.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-510-Counseling-Documents services given'
column5: 'Documents services given'
column6:
'
  • Documentation is part of good clinical practice.
  • Patient follow up is easy when previous records are available.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-520-WE-All supplies available'
column5: 'All supplies available'
column6:
'

Have the necessary supplies including speculums of different sizes, gloves, antiseptic etc.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-530-WE-Light source for genital and speculum examination'
column5: 'Light source for genital and speculum examination'
column6:
'

Have a light source for genital examination so as not to miss a pathology.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-540-WE-STI algorithms and SOPs available'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-540-WE-STI algorithms and SOPs a'
column5: 'STI algorithms and SOPs available'
column6:
'
  • SOPs/flow charts/algorithms represent a combination of practical and scientific information necessary for decision making.
  • These are required for syndromic management of STIs which does not require equipment, are easy to use and ensure immediate provision of services to all clients.
  • SOPs and algorithms need to be followed to provide standardized care and to reduce chances of errors in diagnosis and treatment.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-550-WE-IEC materials'
column5: 'IEC materials'
column6:
'

Have STI IEC materials for distribution

  • Use IEC materials to help change risky sexual health-related behaviors and to reinforce safe practices.
  • The IEC materials should:
    • Have a clear objective to change or reinforce sexual behavior.
    • Target a specific audience e.g. married couples or adolescents
    • Address a specific problems
    • Set a timeframe within which the behavior change is expected to occur.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-560-WE-Condoms'
column5: 'Condoms'
column6:
'

Important to provide condoms to the client to avoid transmitting the STI to partner(s) and to prevent new infection with another STI/HIV.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-600-Inq-Is this a male client?'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-600-Inq-Is this a male client?'
column5: 'Is this a male client?'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-610-Inq-Ensures privacy (Visual and auditory)'
column5: 'Ensures privacy (Visual and auditory)'
column6:
'
  • Ensure the room provides privacy. Patients are often embarrassed and may withhold important information if they think their condition will become known to others.
  • Reassure the patient that confidentiality will be maintained and explain the reason for asking certain questions.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-620-Inq-Provider is polite and non-judgmental'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-620-Inq-Provider is polite and n'
column5: 'Provider is polite and non-judgmental'
column6:
'
  • Create rapport with the patient.
  • Do not create undue barriers to a client seeking STI services.
  • Effective interviewing and counseling skills characterized by respect, compassion, and a nonjudgmental attitude toward all patients are essential to obtaining a thorough sexual history and delivering effective prevention messages.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-630-Inq-Asks about onset and history of current problem relating to the genital area and associated symptoms'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-630-Inq-Asks about onset and his'
column5: 'Asks about onset and history of current problem relating to the genital area and associated symptoms'
column6:
'

Take detailed history

  • Find out the symptoms and their duration. The symptoms to look out for are: genital ulcer/sore, vaginal discharge, pain passing urine, lower abdominal pains.
  • Presumed source and time of infection.
  • Medication, self administered or prescribed.
  • Ask about associated symptoms: fever, intermenstrual bleeding, post-coital bleeding.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-640-Inq-Takes sexual history: type of partner (spouse or casual), date of last encounter, type of exposure (oral, vaginal,anal) regularity of condom use'
column5: 'Takes sexual history: type of partner (spouse or casual), date of last encounter, type of exposure (oral, vaginal,anal) regularity of condom use'
column6:
'

Sexual history

  • Important in determining which STI the patient could be having.
  • Provides the ground for counseling on behaviour change.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-650-Inq-Ask if sexual partner has symptoms'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-650-Inq-Ask if sexual partner ha'
column5: 'Ask if sexual partner has symptoms'
column6:
'

Ask if partner has any symptoms

  • This may help in confirmation of presence of an STI.
  • Introducing discussion on the partner provides an opportunity to counsel on partner tracing and treatment, and to prevent re-infection. However, remember the partner(s) may well be asymptomatic.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-660-Inq-Asks for history of STI in the past, including genital herpes'
column4: 'NG HNQIS STI-660-Inq-Asks for history of STI'
column5: 'Asks for history of STI in the past, including genital herpes'
column6:
'

Ask for history of previous STI infection

  • This may indicate repeated risky behaviour
column7:
repeated exposure from partner or persistence of symptoms from the previous episode.
  • Determine the treatment that was given for the previous STI, if there is history of previous STI.
  • Determine if the sexual partner(s) was treated during the last episode, as the client could be presenting with a re-infection from the same partner.
  • In such a client, emphasize risk reduction. Spend time helping the client to identify a risk reduction plan.
  • Emphasize contact tracing and treatment and have a follow up plan for the client.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-670-Inq-Provider asks about HIV status'
column5: 'Provider asks about HIV status'
column6:
'

Ask about the client''s HIV status

  • A client seeking STI services provides an opportunity for HIV counseling and testing.
  • A client coming for STI screening within 72 hours of sexual exposure and agrees to HIV testing will benefit from HIV post-exposure prophylaxis if the HIV test result turns negative.
  • Behaviors that put someone at risk of STI (not using condoms, multiple partners, anonymous partners) are the same risk factors for HIV infection to oneself and partner.
  • A sore or inflammation from an STD increases the risk of HIV infection.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-680-Inq-Obtains consent before proceeding with examination (verbal) without coercion'
column5: 'Obtains consent before proceeding with examination (verbal) without coercion'
column6:
'
  • Before undertaking any physical examination, seek client or guardian consent.
  • A client has a right to make choices concerning their body/health. As a provider, give all the information required concerning the illness,importance of examination and the procedure to be done to ensure the consent is informed.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-690-PE-Explains the examination procedure and its importance'
column5: 'Explains the examination procedure and its importance'
column6:
'

Explain the examination procedure

  • A client has a right to information regarding their health.
  • Explaining the procedure will allay anxiety and enhance client co-operation during examination especially because genital examinations are embarrassing to most people.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-700-PE-Provider gets a chaperone if the client is not of the same sex'
column5: 'Provider gets a chaperone if the client is not of the same sex'
column6:
'

Have a chaperone during the physical examination

  • This may be another health worker or the partner if they came for treatment together.
  • This will make the client more comfortable.
  • It also helps prevent potential medico-legal complaints regarding sexual/indecent assault against the provider/client.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-710-PE-Prepares equipment and area'
column5: 'Prepares equipment and area'
column6:
'

Prepare equipment and area prior to starting an examination. Have the following supplies/equipment:

  • Examination lamp
  • Examination couch
  • Bi-valved speculums (different sizes)
  • Antiseptic
  • Gloves
  • Lubricant
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-720-PE-Prepares the client adequately'
column5: 'Prepares the client adequately'
column6:
'

Prepare patient adequately

  • Ask the client to empty her bladder for the examination to be more comfortable.
  • Ask her to clean the perineal area if it is soiled.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-730-PE-Ensures privacy during examination'
column5: 'Ensures privacy during examination'
column6:
'

Ensure the door is closed during the examination and draw the curtains around the examination couch.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-740-PE-Washes hands before examination'
column5: 'Washes hands before examination'
column6:
'

Wash hands before and after an encounter with every patient to prevent spread of microorganisms

  • Wash hands with soap and clean running water.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-750-PE-Puts on new gloves'
column5: 'Puts on new gloves'
column6:
'
  • Gloves are important for infection prevention.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-760-PE-Positions the client for examination'
column5: 'Positions the client for examination'
column6:
'
  • Help the woman onto the examination couch.
  • Ask the woman to loosen her clothing. Use a sheet or clothing to cover her.
  • Have her lie on her back, with her heels close to her bottom and her knees up.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-770-PE-Performs a general examination'
column5: 'Performs a general examination'
column6:
'

All examinations should begin with a general assessment, including vital signs and inspection of the skin, to detect signs of systemic disease.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-780-PE-Palpates for inguinal lymph nodes'
column5: 'Palpates for inguinal lymph nodes'
column6:
'

Examine inguinal lymph nodes checking for enlargement, tenderness, consistency and whether they are ,matted or not

  • Inguinal and femoral buboes are localised enlargements of the lymph nodes in the groin area, which are painful and may be fluctuant. They are frequently associated with LGV and chancroid. In many cases of chancroid an associated genital ulcer is visible.
  • However, remember that Non-sexually transmitted local and systemic infections (e.g. infections of the lower limb or tuberculous lymphadenopathy) can also cause swelling of inguinal lymph nodes.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-790-PE-Inspects external genitalia for ulcers, vesicles or urethral discharge
column5: 'NG HNQIS STI-790-PE-Inspects external genital'
column6: 'Inspects external genitalia for ulcers, vesicles or urethral discharge
column8:
'
  • Inspect for ulcers, sores and vesicles on the genitalia.
  • Check for urethral discharge:
    • Most commonly, urethral discharge and dysuria in men are caused by infection with gonorrhea or chlamydia. Occasionally other bacteria are the cause.
    • Scanty clear discharge is more characteristic of chlamydia, and more copious yellow purulent discharge is characteristic of gonorrhea. However, they frequently occur together.
  • In uncircumcised men, discharge from the glans or foreskin may appear to come from the meatus, hence the need to retract the foreskin to determine the source of the discharge.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-800-PE-"Milks" the urethra'
column5: '"Milks" the urethra'
column6:
'
  • If you cannot see an obvious urethral discharge, milk the urethra or ask the patient to milk the urethra gently in order to express any discharge.
  • This is done by applying gentle pressure to the penis.
  • It may be necessary to milk the urethra, starting at the base of the penis. Place one finger or the palm of the hand beneath the penis and one or two fingers on top at the base. Applying gentle pressure, move the hands outward towards the tip of the penis. Repeat the process if necessary.
  • If a discharge is present, wipe it with a swab and dispose of it in a leak-proof container.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-810-PE-Palpates the scrotum, feeling for the testis, epididymis, and spermatic cord on each side'
column5: 'Palpates the scrotum, feeling for the testis, epididymis, and spermatic cord on each side'
column6:
'
  • Palpate the scrotum, feeling for the testis, epididymis, and spermatic cord on each side checking for tenderness.
    • Epididymitis usually manifests itself by acute onset of unilateral testicular pain and swelling, often with tenderness of the epididymis and vas deferens, and occasionally with erythema and oedema of the overlying skin.
    • In men under 35 years this is more frequently caused by sexually transmitted organisms than in those over 35 years.
    • When the epididymitis is accompanied by urethral discharge, it should be presumed to be of sexually transmitted origin, commonly gonococcal and/or chlamydial in nature.
    • The adjacent testis is often also inflamed (orchitis), giving rise to epididymo-orchitis.
    • If not effectively treated, STI-related epididymitis may lead to infertility.
  • It is important to consider other non-infectious causes of scrotal swelling, such as trauma, testicular torsion and tumour.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-820-PE-Examines perianal area'
column5: 'Examines perianal area'
column6:
'

Examine the anal area

  • Ask the patient to lie on her side with the top leg flexed up towards the chest.
  • Examine the anus for ulcers, warts, rashes, or discharge.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-830-Post Exam-Post -examination IP procedures correctly performed'
column5: 'Post -examination IP procedures correctly performed'
column6:
'

Observe infection prevention procedures

  • Immediately soak ALL the instruments used after procedure, or contaminated in any way, in a plastic bucket with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite (chlorine) solution for 10 minutes.
  • Dispose of waste material in leak proof container or plastic bag.
  • Decontaminate couch or other surfaces contaminated during the procedure by wiping with 5% chlorine solution.
  • After soaking for 10 minutes, remove instruments from solution.
  • Clean instruments immediately.
  • Remove gloves following the glove removal procedure.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-840-Post Exam-Washes hands after examination'
column5: 'Washes hands after examination'
column6:
'

Wash hands with soap and running water after examining a patient or performing a procedure to prevent spread of microorganisms.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-850-DxTx-Makes a correct diagnosis'
column5: 'Makes a correct diagnosis'
column6:
'

Identify treatment using the flow charts/algorithms in the STI Diagnosis and Treatment Table

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-860-DxTx-Gives the correct treatment using the standard flow charts/algorithms'
column5: 'Gives the correct treatment using the standard flow charts/algorithms'
column6:
'

Make a diagnosis following the flow charts/algorithms in the STI Diagnosis and Treatment Table

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-870-Counseling-Provider uses education material during counseling'
column5: 'Provider uses education material during counseling'
column6:
'

It is important to use education material to enhance understanding during counseling. The material should cover the critical areas which include:

  • Counseling
  • Compliance to recommended treatment
  • Condoms
  • Contact treatment
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-880-Counseling-Provides information about the current STI, including transmission and prevention'
column5: 'Provides information about the current STI, including transmission and prevention'
column6:
'
  • Inform the client what STI they have.
  • Discuss mechanisms of transmission.
  • Discuss potential health complications that can arise if the STI is not treated e.g. Pelvic infections
column10:
transmission of infection to the new born baby among others.
  • Discuss risky sexual behaviour that increases the risk of getting an STI.
  • Discuss ways of preventing infection with STIs including:
    • delaying sexual activity (for adolescents)
column12:
• using condoms correctly and consistently.
  • early treatment of STI to prevent infection to others.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-890-Counseling-Counsels on drug dosage, duration of treatment including side effects'
column5: 'Counsels on drug dosage, duration of treatment including side effects'
column6:
'

Counsel on proper dosage

  • Counsel on specific doses per day, total number of days of treatment, and potential side effects
column7: including severe side effects that require a return visit to hospital.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-900-Counseling-Provider explores barriers to treatment adherence'
column5: 'Provider explores barriers to treatment adherence'
column6:
'
  • Adherence to treatment and completion of the dose is essential to break the STI transmission cycle and to prevent complications.
  • Explore issues that might hinder treatment such as: fear of spouse/partner discovering they are on treatment for an STI.
  • Discuss with the client ways of tackling the barriers.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-910-Counseling-DOT for single dose drugs offered on site/first dose given on site'
column5: 'DOT for single dose drugs offered on site/first dose given on site'
column6:
'
  • WHO recommends that, where possible, single-dose therapy be used.
  • It is also preferred to initiate treatment as soon as possible.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-920-Counseling-Counsels on risk reduction'
column5: 'Counsels on risk reduction'
column6:
'

Counsel the client on risk reduction to prevent re-infection

  • Abstinence/reduction of number of sexual partners.
  • Correct and consistent condom use.
  • Delaying sexual activity for adolescents and young people.
  • Remaining faithful to one uninfected partner.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-930-Counseling-Counsels on HIV testing and offers the test/refers for the test if the client is willing.'
column5: 'Counsels on HIV testing and offers the test/refers for the test if the client is willing.'
column6:
'
  • Both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs increase the risk of sexual transmission of HIV.
  • A client at risk of STI is also at risk of HIV.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-940-Counseling-Counsels and demonstrates condom use and provides the client with condoms'
column5: 'Counsels and demonstrates condom use and provides the client with condoms'
column6:
'

Condom use

  • Correct and consistent condom use is the most reliable method available method of protecting oneself or their partner from any risk of STIs.
  • STIs can still occur despite condom use: genital ulcers or warts can be transmitted through contact with parts of the body not covered by the condom.
  • Condoms may fail if: handled or stored incorrectly e.g. in wallets or in a hot place
column7:
or if used with oil-based lubricants.
  • Condom breakage is usually due to incorrect use, not due to defects in the device.
  • When used correctly during every act of intercourse, condoms can greatly reduce the risks of both pregnancy and STI (dual protection), including HIV infection.
  • Demonstrate condom use, do not make an assumption that the patient knows how to use condoms.
  • Provide the client with condom supply/ advice client to buy if not available for free distribution.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-950-Counseling-Counsels on contact tracing, partner notification and treatment'
column5: 'Counsels on contact tracing, partner notification and treatment'
column6:
'

Ask the client to bring partner(s) for treatment/advice partner to come for treatment

  • The sexual partner(s) of STI patients are likely to be infected and should be offered treatment.
  • Further transmission of STIs and reinfection can be prevented by referral of sexual partners for diagnosis and treatment.
  • Partner notification and management offers an opportunity to identify and treat people who otherwise would not receive treatment.
  • In case the source of infection was from a casual sexual encounter and there has been no sexual contact with the regular partner/spouse, counsel on importance of preventing transmission to the partner.
  • These actions, however, should be carried out with sensitivity and consideration of social and cultural factors to avoid ethical and practical problems such as rejection and violence, against the woman.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-960-Counseling-Explains re-infection in case the partner is not treated'
column5: 'Explains re-infection in case the partner is not treated'
column6:
'

Emphasize that re-infection will occur if the sexual partner is not treated, regardless of whether the partner is symptomatic or not.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-970-Counseling-Explains where and when to seek follow up care, and gives a follow up visit date'
column5: 'Explains where and when to seek follow up care, and gives a follow up visit date'
column6:
'
  • For continuity of care, it is better for the client to return to the same facility if they have problems.
  • Give the client a number for the facility they can call to ask any question.
  • Give the client a follow up visit if required.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-980-Counseling-Allows the client to ask questions'
column5: 'Allows the client to ask questions'
column6:
'

Always give the client an opportunity to ask questions and to seek clarifications. If you do not give them a chance, they may feel embarrassed to ask and may end up leaving the clinic with a problem or without understanding your instructions.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-990-Counseling-Documents services given'
column5: 'Documents services given'
column6:
'
  • Documentation is part of good clinical practice.
  • Patient follow up is easy when previous records are available.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1000-WE-All supplies available'
column5: 'All supplies available'
column6:
'

Have the necessary supplies including speculums of different sizes, gloves, antiseptic etc.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1010-WE-Light source for genital and speculum examination'
column5: 'Light source for genital and speculum examination'
column6:
'

Have a light source for genital examination so as not to miss a pathology.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1020-WE-STI algorithms and SOPs available'
column5: 'STI algorithms and SOPs available'
column6:
'
  • SOPs/flow charts/algorithms represent a combination of practical and scientific information necessary for decision making.
  • These are required for syndromic management of STIs which does not require equipment, are easy to use and ensure immediate provision of services to all clients.
  • SOPs and algorithms need to be followed to provide standardized care and to reduce chances of errors in diagnosis and treatment.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1030-WE-IEC materials'
column5: 'IEC materials'
column6:
'

Have STI IEC materials for distribution

  • Use IEC materials to help change risky sexual health-related behaviors and to reinforce safe practices.
  • The IEC materials should:
    • Have a clear objective to change or reinforce sexual behavior.
    • Target a specific audience e.g. married couples or adolescents
    • Address a specific problems
    • Set a timeframe within which the behavior change is expected to occur.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1040-WE-Condoms'
column5: 'Condoms'
column6:
'

Important to provide condoms to the client to avoid transmitting the STI to partner(s) and to prevent new infection with another STI/HIV.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS STI-1050-END-END OF TAB'
column5: 'END OF TAB'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1650-EC-Does this facility offer Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs)?'
column5: 'Does this facility offer Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs)?'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1660-EC-Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1660-EC-Is this a real or simulat'
column5: 'Is this a real or simulated observation?'
column6:
'

Real observations are preferred

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1670-EC-Confirms eligibility for ECPs'
column5: 'Confirms eligibility for ECPs'
column6:
'
  • Confirm to the woman that all women can use ECPs safely and effectively, including women who cannot use ongoing hormonal contraceptive methods.
  • Because of the short-term nature of their use, there are no medical conditions that make ECPs unsafe for any woman.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1680-EC-Tells the client about ECPs, how they work, effectiveness and possible side effects'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1680-EC-Tells the client about EC'
column5: 'Tells the client about ECPs, how they work, effectiveness and possible side effects'
column6:
'
  • ECPs work primarily by preventing or delaying ovulation.
  • Effective when taken within 5 days of having unprotected sex
column7:
the sooner they are taken, the more effective.
  • Do not disrupt an existing pregnancy.
  • Side effects include: changes in bleeding pattern

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1690-EC-Checks expiry date'
column5: 'Checks expiry date'
column6:
'

Always check the expiry date
Do not give expired pills to a patient.

'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1700-EC-Gives/explains to the client the correct number of pills and how to take them'
column5: 'Gives/explains to the client the correct number of pills and how to take them'
column6:
'

Explain the number of pills and the dosing schedule. This depends on the type of ECP

  • Levonorgestrel-only dedicated product: 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel in a single dose.
  • Estrogen-progestin dedicated product: 0.1 mg ethinyl estradiol + 0.5 mg levonorgestrel. Follow with same dose 12 hours later.
  • Progestin-only pills with levonorgestrel: levonorgestrel pills: 1.5 mg levonorgestrel in a single dose.
  • Progestin-only pills with norgestrel: 3 mg norgestrel in a single dose.
  • Combined (estrogen-progestin) oral contraceptives containing levonorgestrel: Estrogen and levonorgestrel pills: 0.1 mg ethinyl estradiol + 0.5 mg levonorgestrel. Follow with same dose 12 hours later.
  • Combined (estrogen-progestin) oral contraceptives containing norgestrel: Estrogen and norgestrel pills: 0.1 mg ethinyl estradiol + 1 mg norgestrel. Follow with same dose 12 hours later.
  • Combined (estrogen-progestin) oral contraceptives containing norethindrone: Estrogen and norethindrone pills: 0.1 mg ethinyl estradiol + 2 mg norethindrone. Follow with same dose 12 hours later.
  • Ulipristal acetate dedicated product: 30 mg of ulipristal acetate in a single dose.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1710-EC-Provider explains how to manage possible side effects'
column5: 'Provider explains how to manage possible side effects'
column6:
'

Explain what to do about side effects

  • Nausea: routine use of anti-nausea medications is not recommended. Women who have had nausea with previous ECP use or with the first dose of a 2-dose regimen can take anti-nausea medication one-half to one hour before taking ECPs.
  • Vomiting: if vomiting occurs within 2 hours of taking ECPs, the dose should be repeated. (She can use anti-nausea medication with this repeat dose, as above.) If vomiting continues, she can take the repeat dose by placing the pills high in her vagina. If vomiting occurs more than 2 hours after taking ECPs, she does not need to take any extra pills.
  • Change in bleeding pattern: will eventually regularize without treatment. Not a problem unless irregular bleeding is due to a pregnancy if the ECPs fail.
  • The rest of the side effects should pass without requiring treatment.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1720-EC-Explains that the next menstrual period may start earlier or later'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1720-EC-Explains that the next me'
column5: 'Explains that the next menstrual period may start earlier or later'
column6:
'
  • Monthly bleeding may start earlier or later than expected.
  • This is not a sign of illness or pregnancy.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1730-EC-Informs client to return for a pregnancy test if her menses are more than one week late'
column5: 'Informs client to return for a pregnancy test if her menses are more than one week late'
column6:
'
  • If her next monthly bleeding is more than one week later than expected after taking ECPs, assess for pregnancy.
  • There are no known risks to a fetus conceived if ECPs fail to prevent pregnancy.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1740-EC-Allows the client to ask questions and checks clients'' understanding'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1740-EC-Allows the client to ask'
column5: 'Allows the client to ask questions and checks clients'' understanding'
column6:
'

Confirm understanding and allow the client to ask questions

  • Will ensure she takes the medicine the correct way.
  • Any other issues can be addressed.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1750-EC-Informs client to return, or call if she has any questions or concerns'
