column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1810-IUD for EC-Screening'
column5: 'Screening'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1820-IUD for EC-Provider uses the "Checklist for Screening a Client Who Wants to Initiate Use of the Copper IUD as Emergency Contraception"'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1820-IUD for EC-Provider uses the'
column5: 'Provider uses the "Checklist for Screening a Client Who Wants to Initiate Use of the Copper IUD as Emergency Contraception"'
column6:
'
  • This tool is intended to be used by providers who are screening women that are seeking emergency contraception (EC) to prevent an unintended pregnancy.
  • It will enable accurate determination as to which client may receive an IUD an emergency contraception.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1830-IUD for EC-Provider confirms Medical Eligibility for the IUD'
column5: 'Provider confirms Medical Eligibility for the IUD'
column6:
'

The following are contraindications to IUD insertion

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding: may be a sign of an underlying pathological condition, such as genital malignancy or a pregnancy-related problem.
  • Any type of cancer in the genital organs, trophoblastic disease, or pelvic tuberculosis.
  • Multiple sexual partners/partner with multiple sexual partners: more than one sexual partner in the last 3 months. Clients who have multiple sexual partners are at high risk of contracting STIs.
  • Diagnosis of STI in the last 3 months: there is a possibility that these clients currently have chlamydia and/or gonorrhea infection. Unless these STIs can be reliably ruled out, do not insert IUD.
  • Partner has had an STI in the last 3 months, or if he has had any symptoms - for example, penile discharge.
  • Patient with AIDS and not on ARVs: HIV-positive clients who have developed AIDS and are not taking ARVs may be at increased risk of STIs and PID because of a suppressed immune system. IUD use may further increase that risk. If the woman is HIV-positive but has not developed AIDS, the IUD may generally be used.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1840-IUD for EC-Pre-insertion'
column5: 'Pre-insertion'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1850-IUD for EC-Provider washes hands'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1850-IUD for EC-Provider washes h'
column5: 'Provider washes hands'
column6:
'

Wash hands before and after an encounter with every patient to prevent spread of microorganisms

  • Wash hands with soap and clean running water.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1860-IUD for EC-Prepares the environment'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1860-IUD for EC-Prepares the envi'
column5: 'Prepares the environment'
column6:
'
  • Ensure adequate lighting and both visual and auditory privacy.
  • Close door and draw curtains around the patient.
  • Do not expose the patient until you are ready to start the procedure.
  • Ensure that your conversation with the patient cannot be heard by anyone else.
  • Have an examination lamp and position it to illuminate the perineum.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1870-IUD for EC-Prepares insertion equipment and area'
column5: 'Prepares insertion equipment and area'
column6:
'

Assemble all the necessary equipment before starting
This is a sterile procedure. Prepare before starting the procedure to avoid movements after starting the procedure that might compromise infection prevention. Display all the requirements on a sterile surface. The following requirements should be made ready before the procedure:

  • Examination light,
  • Copper T IUCD (sealed and not expired),
  • Bivalve speculums (several sizes),
  • Tenaculum,
  • Uterine sound,
  • Sponge holding forceps,
  • Scissors (for trimming IUD strings),
  • Sterile gauze,
  • Sterile gloves,
  • Sterile drapes,
  • Lubricant,
  • Antiseptic solution.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1880-IUD for EC-Prepares the client appropriately'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1880-IUD for EC-Prepares the clie'
column5: 'Prepares the client appropriately'
column6:
'

Check that patient emptied her bladder and washed her genital area if necessary

  • Emptying the bladder makes the speculum examination more comfortable and avoids pressure on the bladder wall.
  • Fecal matter soiling in the perennial area should be cleaned to avoid contamination since it is a sterile procedure.
  • Help client onto exam table.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1890-IUD for EC-Performs abdominal exam (Palpation)'
column5: 'Performs abdominal exam (Palpation)'
column6:
'

Perform an abdominal examination to rule out pelvic masses and pelvic inflammatory disease

  • Observe the abdomen for scars, swelling or visible lesions.
  • Check for swellings, bulges, masses, or other gross abnormalities.
  • Check for suprapubic tenderness.
  • If there are any abnormalities, do not insert the IUD. Give her the option of emergency contraceptive pills and investigate and manage for the abnormality found.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1900-IUD for EC-Appropriately performs a speculum examination'
column5: 'Appropriately performs a speculum examination'
column6:
'
  • Position her in lithotomy position.
  • Wear sterile gloves on both hands.
  • Clean the perineum and external genitalia .
  • Inspect the external genitalia for any ulcers.
  • Insert the speculum and:
    • Inspect the cervix and vaginal canal for ulcers-may indicate a current STI
column7: • Check for purulent cervical discharge- may be a sign of cervicitis and possibly PID
column8: • Check if cervix bleeds easily to touch-may indicate cervicitis or cervical cancer
column9:
• Any anatomical abnormality of the cervix that may prevent insertion of IUD.
    • '

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1910-IUD for EC-Performs a bimanual exam'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1910-IUD for EC-Performs a bimanu'
column5: 'Performs a bimanual exam'
column6:
'

Perform Bimanual examination:

  • Note the size, shape, position and mobility of the uterus.
  • Assess for adnexal tenderness or masses-Adnexa tenderness or/and adnexa mass is a sign of a malignancy or PID.
  • Assess for cervical motion tenderness- a sign of PID.
  • Is there an anatomical abnormality of the uterine cavity that distorts the uterine cavity?
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1920-IUD for EC-Appropriately makes decision whether woman is eligible for IUD as EC and informs her.'
column5: 'Appropriately makes decision whether woman is eligible for IUD as EC and informs her.'
column6:
'
  • The decision to insert the IUD as EC depends on the screening checklist and examination findings.
  • If the woman is not eligible, counsel appropriately and you may offer emergency contraceptive pills if she is eligible.
  • If she is eligible, counsel her on the next steps of insertion.
'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1930-IUD for EC-Insertion'
column5: 'Insertion'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1940-IUD for EC-Swabs cervix three times with antiseptic'
column4: 'NG HNQIS FP-1940-IUD for EC-Swabs cervix thre'
column5: 'Swabs cervix three times with antiseptic'
column6:
'

IUCD insertion is a sterile procedure and swabbing the cervix three times minimizes the risk of introducing infection into the uterus.

  • Cleanse from the center of the cervical os moving outward on the cervix and into the surrounding vaginal canal.
  • If povidone iodine is used, allow 1 to 2 minutes before proceeding.
  • Do not use alcohol as it is painful for the woman
column7: dries and damages the mucous membranes, which may support the infectious process.'

column3: 'NG HNQIS FP-1950-IUD for EC-Correctly performs IUCD insertion based on protocols or guidelines'
column5: 'Correctly performs IUCD insertion based on protocols or guidelines'
column6:
'
  1. Gently grasp the cervix with tenaculum at 12 o''clock position and apply gentle traction. This is to align the uterus with the cervical opening and to stabilize the cervix for easier insertion of the IUD. Close the tenaculum only to the first notch to minimize discomfort.
  2. Sound the uterus using no-touch technique.This will ensure you insert the IUCD at the uterine fundus, by adjusting the blue flange to the corresponding uterine length as measured during sounding.
    • If the IUCD is inserted at the low uterine segment, pregnancy can occur because implantation takes place in the uterine fundus.
    • Use the no-touch technique to minimize risk of infection.
    • Steps of uterine sounding:
      • Gently pull the tenaculum to align the uterus and cervical opening.
      • Insert the uterine sound into the cervical opening.
      • Advance the sound into the uterine cavity until a slight resistance is felt.
      • Note the angle of the uterine cavity, and gently remove the sound. Do not pass the sound into the uterus more than once.
      • Mark length of the uterus by observing the mucus line on the tenaculum or marking with sponge holding forceps. The average uterus is between 6 and 8 cm in depth. If the uterus is less than 6 cm in depth, the woman may be at increased risk for IUD expulsion.
      • Slowly withdraw the sound.
      • On sounding the uterus, if the uterine cavity is irregular or deeper than 10 cm,do not insert IUD. Explain to the patient that with an enlarged uterus the IUD may not be as effective as normally expected and help the woman to consider another method.
  3. Load the IUCD
    • Adjust the contents of the package inside the insertion tube such that the vertical stem of the T is fully inside the insertion tube.
    • Set the depth-gauge (blue flange) to reflect the uterine length as measured by the uterine sound.
    • Open at the bottom end (where arrow says OPEN).
    • Insert the white rod into the insertion tube, until up to the level of the blue flange.
    • Load the IUCD by folding its arms and placing them inside the insertion tube while still in its sterile pack (no-touch technique) by placing the package face up on a clean surface. Place thumb and index finger on top of package on ends of the horizontal arms. Use other hand to push insertion tube against arms of, this will start bending the T arms and loading the IUCD. Do not bend the arms of copper T for more than 5 minutes before it is placed in the uterus.
    • Align the blue flange and the folded arms of the copper T so that they are both in a horizontal plane.
    • Remove the loaded IUD from the package:
  4. Insert the IUD using withdrawal technique:
    • Put on a new pair of sterile gloves on both hands.
    • Gently grasp the tenaculum (still in place from sounding the uterus) and apply gentle traction.
    • Insert the loaded IUCD by holding the insertion tube, without touching vaginal walls or speculum blades, keeping the horizontal plane.
    • Gently advance the loaded IUCD into the uterine cavity.
    • STOP when the blue flange comes in contact with the cervix or light resistance is felt.
    • Hold the tenaculum and white plunger rod stationary, while partially withdrawing the insertion tube - this releases the arms of the IUCD.
    • Gently push the insertion tube until you feel a slight resistance - this step ensures placement high in the uterus.
    • Remove the white plunger rod, while holding the insertion tube stationary.
    • Gently and slowly withdraw the inserter tube from the cervical canal until strings can be seen protruding from the cervical opening.
    • IMPORTANT: Do not pass the loaded IUD into the uterus more than once.
  5. Cut strings:
    • Use sharp Mayo scissors to cut the IUCD strings at 3-4 cm from the cervical opening before completely removing the inserter tube. (This technique ensures that the pieces of cut‐off string will stay in the insertion tube for easy disposal.)
    • Completely withdraw insertion tube with cut ends of strings inside.
    • Gently remove the tenaculum.
    • Observe the cervix for bleeding and remove speculum.
column8:
>
  • Reposition patient and make her comfortable. Observe her for 15-20 minutes before assisting her out of the bed.
    • ';'RESbZFLeS8E';1950;0.40;0.40;146;53;;169 912;'NG HNQIS FP-1960';'NG HNQIS FP-1960-IUD for EC-Post insertion';'NG HNQIS FP-1960-IUD for EC-Post insertion';'Post insertion';;'G1fwQlvfciH';1960;0.00;0.00;146;49;;169 913;'NG HNQIS FP-1970';'NG HNQIS FP-1970-IUD for EC-Post insertion IP procedures correctly performed';'NG HNQIS FP-1970-IUD for EC-Post insertion IP';'Post insertion IP procedures correctly performed';'

    Follow infection prevention procedures

    • Immediately soak ALL the instruments used for procedure or contaminated in any way, in a plastic bucket with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite (chlorine) solution for 10 minutes.
    • Dispose of waste material in leak proof container or plastic bag.
    • Decontaminate couch or other surfaces contaminated during the procedure by wiping with 5% chlorine solution.
    • After soaking for 10 minutes, remove instruments from solution.
    • Clean instruments immediately.
    • Remove gloves following the glove removal procedure.
    ';'pXVDqm9Sh4m';1970;0.05;0.05;146;53;;169 914;'NG HNQIS FP-1980';'NG HNQIS FP-1980-IUD for EC-Provider offers post-insertion counseling';'NG HNQIS FP-1980-IUD for EC-Provider offers p';'Provider offers post-insertion counseling';'

    Counseling points

    • If next menses come when expected. Then she may not be pregnant.
    • She can consider keeping the IUD for regular contraception.
      • If she chooses to keep it, she should come for a follow-up 3-6 weeks after insertion.
      • If she doesn''t want to continue using an IUD, she can have it removed any time after the start of her menses. She will then need another contraceptive method to prevent pregnancy.
    • If next menses do not come when expected
    • She is most likely pregnant. Advice her to return for a pregnancy test one week after expected menses.
      • If pregnancy test positive, advice her on options available.
      • If pregnancy test negative, she may chose to keep it or remove it. Offer alternative FP method if she choses to remove.
    • Explain that the IUD does not protect against STI/HIV.
    • The IUCD can be removed any time if she desires.
    • Explain that cramping, light bleeding may occur immediately after IUCD insertion and may last for a few days. These symptoms are not harmful and do not indicate a problem. For cramping, advise her to take paracetamol or ibuprofen . If the symptoms become bothersome the woman can come back to the health facility.
    • The following symptoms, (PAINS) warrants immediate return to the health facility:
      • Period related or Pregnancy related problems:
      • Abdominal pain or pain during intercourse,
      • Infections or unusual vaginal discharge,
      • Not feeling well, fever, chills,
      • String problems,
    • If she chooses to keep the IUD as an ongoing contraceptive method, ask her to check for strings during menses. Advice her to come back to the health facility, if the strings are missing.
    • Give the woman a review/reminder card and indicate the return date on the card. Remind her that she can come to the health facility whenever a complication occurs.
    ';'lAsWu8hjYGT';1980;0.03;0.03;146;53;;169 915;'NG HNQIS FP-1990';'NG HNQIS FP-1990-IUD for EC-Assesses client´s physical wellbeing before discharge';'NG HNQIS FP-1990-IUD for EC-Assesses client´s';'Assesses client´s physical wellbeing before discharge';'

    Post insertion assessment

    • Ask patient if she has nausea, abdominal cramping, dizziness or fainting (touching the cervix can cause neurogenic shock, though rarely).
    • If symptoms persist after 30 min, examine her for evidence of peritoneal signs which may indicate a perforation.
    • If no evidence of peritonitis, offer the woman an analgesic such as paracetamol or ibuprofen and observer for another 10‐15 minutes.
    • If the woman is stable she may be discharged.
    • If definite peritoneal signs are present, the woman should be examined by a provider who may feel that further observation or intervention are necessary.
    ';'bAZB1D5Mzxo';1990;0.08;0.08;146;53;;169 916;'NG HNQIS FP-2000';'NG HNQIS FP-2000-IUD for EC-Records service in the client file and register / log book';'NG HNQIS FP-2000-IUD for EC-Records service i';'Records service in the client file and register / log book';'

    Record services provided in the patient file and daily activity register/log book. Documentation is part of good clinical practice.

    ';'eZkj8C1npp0';2000;0.01;0.01;146;53;;169 917;'NG HNQIS FP-2010';'NG HNQIS FP-2010-IUD for EC-Work Environment- IUD for Emergency Contraception';'NG HNQIS FP-2010-IUD for EC-Work Environment-';'Work Environment- IUD for Emergency Contraception';;'rpSZPbvQp2t';2010;0.00;0.00;146;49;;169 918;'NG HNQIS FP-2020';'NG HNQIS FP-2020-IUD for EC-The following are available: tenaculum, uterine sound, bi‐valve speculums, long scissors, sponge‐holding forceps, gallipots, kidney dish.';'NG HNQIS FP-2020-IUD for EC-The following equ';'The following are available: tenaculum, uterine sound, bi‐valve speculums, long scissors, sponge‐holding forceps, gallipots, kidney dish.';'

    It is important to have all the insertion equipment to ensure you perform the procedure correctly. This will ensure safety of the patient and accurate insertion to reduce the chances of perforation, failure or expulsion of the IUD.

    ';'aQwORbWjp72';2020;0.05;0.05;146;53;;169 919;'NG HNQIS HIV-269';'NG HNQIS HIV-269-Care Tx-Does this facility offer HIV Care and Treatment?';'NG HNQIS HIV-269-Care Tx-Does this facility o';'Does this facility offer HIV Care and Treatment?';;'O9fT18jF4oA';269;0.00;0.00;97;53;;133
